description:
I was enjoying a sunny Saturday up and down Valencia.  I was doing my normal boutique hopping when hunger pangs started hitting.  Fortunately I was in the Mission--so many choices!  I got excited as the prospect of so many taquerias within my reach.  I started to march down Valencia to the nearest taco joint when I walked by a small Vietnamese restaurant.  I looked at the menu posted outside and saw the menu size and prices--small and respectable, respectively.  I peered through the window to see the interior--a Vietnamese family behind the counter, and a small handful of patrons dining in the cramped space.  It was enough to lure me in.  Thanh Tam is a typical Vietnamese restaurant--weathered, lacking in ambiance, but with a healthy waft of Vietnamese food smells hitting you in the face when you walk in.  

I ordered com thit nuong cha gio, and the plate immediately came out hot and freshly dressed (yes, I'm still talking about food).  The portion size was HUGE.  Everything was fresh and just what I expected.  The egg roll had the rice paper wrapper, which is always a huge bonus for me.  I wolfed down the delicious food, but to my surprise, I couldn't clean my plate--there's a fat girl who lives inside me, and if I can't finish a plate, that means it was BIG.  I paid my tab and walked out of Thanh Tam $12 poorer but exponentially happier.  The only bad thing is that this place will undoubtedly continue to distract me from trying the myriad of great tacos in the Mission.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Place says it's open. 

Door open. 

Says open on yelp. 

Inside, a family is finishing up their meal. 
I sit down and notice that the wait staff and the cooks are sitting down for their lunch/dinner at the table next to mine. 

I continue to sit and wait for someone to either take my order or tell me that they're closed. 

5 min go by and the only thing I hear from them is their slurping as they eat their soups. 

I get up and leave.
author: Rusty B.

description:
Thanh Tam II has $6 bahn mi sandwiches and for that reason I give it 5 stars. (plus they big are freaking delicious too.)

My friends have eaten the pho and other items and said they were typical and tasty.
author: Howie M.

description:
Solid Thai place but nothing all that great in my opinion. Came with a party of 8 for a late lunch on a Saturday and was pleasantly surprised that we were seated right away. The service here was overall pretty nice.

My friend and I split the Spring Rolls, which were alright but tasted kinda bland. There was shrimp and pork in it but I could barely taste anything. The pho here was equally mediocre. The broth was not as flavorful as some other place I've been to, but maybe that's just me be
author: Josh B.

description:
I like Thanh Tam II as my hole in the wall place for vegan pho. It's not excellent, but it's not bad, it's just...reasonably priced, OK pho that does the job. It also wasn't exactly the same each time I went, but consistent enough for me.

It's nice to have a reasonably priced option in SF!
author: Christina M.

description:
I've been to Thanh Tam twice and had an enjoyable pho experience both times. I love that they have a lot of vegetarian and vegan options. I love their vegan pho! 

I didn't have to wait to be seated and the food came out fairly quickly. I will be back!
author: Kelly F.

description:
A little Vietnamese joint not far from the Mission BART station that gets insanely busy at lunch.  It's not quite as good as the pho in Little Saigon (I just love Bodega Bistro), but better than a lot of pho outside of Little Saigon.  Great if you're in the hood on a chilly day.

Beef Pho w/ Rare Steak, Beef Ball, Flank: Hit the spot on a rainy winter day!  The large is quite filling with tons of noodles and broth.  I got my reliable trio of meats (since I don't like tripe and tendon).  The beef balls had that satisfying squishiness.  The rare steak wasn't that rare by the time it got to me and was a bit thicker cut than usual, but still tasty.  Wasn't a huge fan of the flank though since it had way more fatty parts than meaty parts.  Broth was on point.
author: Adam B.

description:
I've had a lot of Vietnamese food in my lifetime. Like, a lot. So I know what it's like to have THE best. 

Stopped by this place for the first time with a friend, ordered the beef vermicelli bowl w egg rolls, a fave of mine. 

First off, it took the waiter forever to come over and ask what we'd wanted to order - didn't let this sway my experience for the negative tho. 

Got my bowl and was surprised to see very little meat. Took a couple bites and the meat was so dry it almost tasted and felt like beef jerky. Yikes. 

Overall, my experience was just okay. The price was good but I was not impressed by the least. I will not be returning.
author: Cody J.

description:
When you're not looking to make it all the way to Oakland or San Jose for some authentic Vietnamese food, Thanh Tam II is a pretty good choice located in the Mission District. I've been a number of times and never needed to wait to be seated since there's ample seating. There's always a few groups eating but takeout is popular as well.

As for the food, the Bahn Xeo (Vietnamese savory pancake filled with shrimp & bean sprouts and served with lettuce & mint) is delicious and although it's listed under appetizer, it's more than enough food for an entree. The Shrimp & Pork Roll are pretty good as well. 

I enjoyed the Grilled Pork Vermicelli w/ Imperial Roll. It does come with a lot of noodles which I couldn't finish. I definitely needed to ask for more fish sauce to soak up the noodles.  

In terms of the soup, I find them to be a bit lacking. The Pho was decent but didn't have too much variety in terms of the meats (the sliced meat it came with was a bit dry) and the soup also came out room temperature. The Bun Bo Hue looked similar to the pho and was skimpy in terms of what you'd normally expect from the soup. There was no pig's blood as well as all the other meats & veggies that typically come with Bun Bo Hue.

The staff is friendly.. they speak Vietnamese & Cantonese. There's a t.v. at the front of the restaurant by the cashier so you can likely watch a game if it's on. Street parking in the area is limited so you're better off grabbing an Uber.
author: Ruby C.

description:
RUDE STAFF - YELLED AT CHILDREN! Our family used to go to this place as much as we could for comfort Vietnamese food in a no frills environment. We went last night with our two young kids (2 & 6), as we sat down, my 2 year old started handing out chopsticks to all of us. In the process, he knocked over the cheap plastic holder for the chopsticks. The waiter was taking an order in the table next door, turned around and started yelling that "CHILDREN ARE NOT ALLOWED TO PLAY WITH CHOPSTICKS. IT IS AGAINST RESTAURANT POLICY." I was so shocked, first of all, when do you have a POLICY not allowing children to play with chopsticks. Secondly, my son was handing over chopsticks to our family, he was not playing. I tried to explain this to the waiter multiple times, and he didn't seem to care. He kept yelling that children are not allowed to use chopsticks in the restaurant. I had enough, picked up my stuff, my two young kids, and walked out, telling him he has lost customers and I will never come back. This is how he responded, "I don't care. You go, go go, get lost." Yes, DISRESPECTFUL MAN, yelling not only at children but a mother who is there in presence of her two kids. Other customers were all shaking their heads and sympathizing with me. Of course, I had a few choice words for him as I walked out, but didn't unleash my wrath because I had to stay as calm as I could in front of my kids. To the workers and owner of the restaurant: I don't care how good or authentic your food is, i am absolutely DISGUSTED by this human who has no decency and does not treat CHILDREN OR WOMEN with respect. NO ONE COMES TO YOUR RESTAURANT TO PUT UP WITH YOUR TERRIBLE BEHAVIOR. You yelled at my kids in front of other customers for something like chopsticks... you are a terrible person. You say your business is good for kids? NO, it's NOT, YOU LIE!

FYI, I have a photo of this guy, once I figure out how I can post photos, I will add it on Yelp for sure.
author: Zoey F.

description: Legit Viet food at a decent price . Mau is cool Viet spot but not really authentic nor cheap like Vietnamese usually is. Take out the frills and whatever, you're left with some decent food here
author: Morethankimchi J.

description: Decent pho, delicious chicken wings, RUDE service!  Both the waiter and cashier were pills and had a look of disdain on their face.  They both made me feel like I was a burden.  Please get laid!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Okay I don't know if I've just been getting lucky with this place, but I LOVE it! 

Have only had it through delivery twice but it's been so good and flavorful each time. I order the prawn wonton soup with egg noodle and my friend gets the combo beef noodle soup.

Both of us eat the entire bowl each time haha. Obviously I have no idea how it is to visit in person, but either way I'll keep getting it to go or delivered. 

I'm picky when it comes to pho and noodle soup overall and the broth is super yummmm! Crossing my fingers they stay on Doordash and Postmates.
author: Heather H.

description: Went with my friend and was disappointed by the service. Very rude staff.
author: Melissa C.

description:
This place used to be located in the excelsior district right by the excelsior library and family owned! Growing up, I used to remember walking to this place with my mom to order take out and every time we went inside, it would smell soo good. Then it closed down and we had no idea that it had moved! For the next 10+ years or so, we would often talk about this place and how amazing their broth was and their grilled beef with vermicelli noodles! 

One day, my mom dug up their business card and did a quick Google search and found their new location!!! We knew we had to pay them a visit again. Now for the last few years, kevins noodle house has been my to go favorite. My boyfriend and mom ordered the pho and I ordered spring rolls since I was too full from eating all day. I did try their pho and soup though and it was still as good as I remembered it to be. We asked for beef on the side but they forgot and accidentally put it in with the soup. The owner was nice enough and gave us two extra plates of beef on the side. If youre a fan of kevins, their soup is comparable or even better! This place has a stronger broth taste while kevins has a more clear broth taste. 

Will come back again and order my own bowl of pho next time!
author: Denise J.

description:
Came here as part of my mission to try every Vietnamese place in SF. I probably had been to about 30 before this one, and overall, it was a decent experience. 

We ordered a tofu and mixed veggie plate, beef vermicelli, and rare beef flank pho. The veggies were cooked in a light brown sauce with the Asian style fried tofu I love and the pho was probably the LARGEST bowl I have ever gotten (for less than $9!). However, both dishes lacked a lot of flavor, and I found myself adding more sodium-heavy condiments than I would have liked, in attempts to amp up the flavor. I tried the vermicelli and it also seemed to lack some kick, but overall the portions were generous and reasonably priced. I think I was partially disappointed because several SF guides rate this place's pho in the top 10 or so... but I'm guessing part of that is because of the size to price ratio.
author: Quinn Li O.

description: This place is good for a quick pho fix. The food is satisfying and the service is fast. The reason for the 3 stars is that the flavor just wasn't all there- the soup tasted almost too clean. After adding copious amount of spice to it, it still was just ok. Overall, if you need a quick fix for pho and are in the area- it's a good choice.. but I'll keep looking around the city for some pho.
author: Nadia H.

description:
Wow! This place is delicious. First time eating and ordering off a food app, and I am not disappointed. 

I ordered the grilled sliced pork over rice. Weirdly enough the plate I received didn't come with rice - but they must have know I'm on the keto lifestyle! #ThanksForLookingOut

Can't wait to order from this place again. 

p.s the food was still warm when it arrived #6stars for that!
author: Amy Y.

description:
I've been here twice recently, once (#1) for a dine-in dinner and once (#2) for take-out. The first was a 4.5 experience, the other was 3.5, thus the 4-star average you see here. 

#1: After a wonderful afternoon of tennis + beers in Dolores Park, took my tennis partner to Thanh Tam for authentic Viet dishes. The restaurant is cozy, with cool lighting and a welcoming atmosphere. Service was quick and friendly. After much deliberation (everything looks so good), decided on sesame beef and shrimp over rice, as well as bbq pork and egg roll over vermicelli (bun). Both dishes  had pretty good portion and lots of flavor. Not much in the spice department, but no worries: chili sauce in ketchup bottles in close reach! Also 100% asked for jalapeños on the side, which were soon provided. We ended up quite satisfied with our dishes. I would give that experience a 4.5, but that could have been influenced by the pleasure of my company :)

#2: I was on the BART back from work (Alameda by way of Fruitvale) and suddenly had a major craving for banh mi. Nothing else could have satiated this desire, so I called Thanh Tam as soon as I hit my station, and ordered the banh mi with everything (pickled carrots and daikon, cilantro, jalapeños, mayo, soy sauce, onions) minus cucumber. I didn't really pick up the onion or soy sauce, but the meat was decent and the sandwich was ultimately enjoyable. However, their $10 minimum was unexpected / not pleasantly stated to me, and the walk home / back / home was less than savory. With that said, at $6.47 after tax, I could see myself warming up to the idea of take-out banh mi from here in the future.

All in all, a wonderful family-run restaurant with a very local vibe, as opposed to some of the other 'trendy' Viet restaurants in the Mission. Check it out!
author: Anish T.

description:
Thanh Tam II is a solid, but un-extraordinary place for pho and Vietnamese food in the Mission. 

It's a bit small and easy to miss, the service is quick and straightforward, and the prices are pretty standard. I've had the Bun Bo Hue and Chicken Pho, and both were exactly what I expected--good, but nothing special. 

Be mindful of their $10 credit card minimum. Most main dishes are $9 plus so with tax, you should be good :) I'm still on the hunt for the best Vietnamese joint in the Mission, so will be trying Mau and Sunflower next!
author: Tim X.

description:
siiiiiiick viet place. After trying out 2 other bars to watch the warriors game we quietly slipped into a center table at Thanh Tam II. My friend got this fish cakes stir fry (which was amazingly crispy and good), and I got one of those crispy egg noodles with shrimp and chicken and beef which I've been craving for a minute.

Check it out tho.
author: Willy X.

description:
It really bothers me to see all these poor reviews of this restaurant. This place consistently delivers excellent Vietnamese food every single time. I've tried so many Vietnamese restaurants in the city and this one is my favorite and thankfully they're just a couple blocks down from where I live. Their 5  spice chicken is to die for!  At other  restaurants, five spice chicken is super oily and is fried but not here. It's amazing, I believe it's grilled.  Their chicken Pho is so flavorful and everything I've tried on the menu has been excellent.
Hands down this is one of my favorite restaurants  in SF, I come here about once a week.
author: Reena T.

description: Great little spot to satisfy my pho cravings. I had the Pho Tai large which was a bit smaller than I was expecting (for the price) but plenty to fill me up. Would have been happier with a little more broth. The flavors were spot on and all the normal accompaniments were fresh and plentiful. Will definitely come back to try other combos!
author: James B.

description: I found a hidden Vietnamese spot in the mission for some delicious pan fried mix vegetables noodles. I devoured the the plate.
author: rob a.

description:
Great food! My friend and I didn't know what to expect at the beginning, because the door doesn't have a great sign, only the menu; coming in we didn't see the place crowed, as usually what are considered "good places are" (maybe because the time of the day?) but I can say it was great!! It brought us back to Asia. 
The fried rolls are awesome (the sweet sauce is the best).
Wanton soup was really tasty, fried rice as well. 
I will definitely go back!
author: Bella C.

description: Perfect for cold nights! The pho was extremely satisfying when we were freezing our butts off outside. It's quiet, warm, and service is very fast.
author: Vivian C.

description:
You can still get a sit down meal for $10! At Than Tam II the portions are extremely generous, very diverse and brought to you super fast. Ideal location for a pretty fresh, very affordable and no fuss kind of meal. 

While most of San Francisco is waiting in line for a trendy restaurant or grabbing another burrito, mix it up and join the locals in the neighborhood for a basic but also very practical Vietnamese meal. 

The decor is a little weird (it's perpetually Christmas?) but this place is a step up from a straight up hole in the wall. It's also one of the few places I've seen lots of people eating alone. 

Most people are ordering vermicelli noodle bowls or the pho. Both quite good. I also usually get a clay pot fish, which is very peppery but compliments the fresh noodle bowl nicely. 

They do delivery at dinner time for orders of $20 and above - haven't tried that option myself but I'm guessing you can get a truckload of food for that price point!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Good value for this small Vietnamese joint in the Mission. Stopped by on a Tuesday afternoon at 4pm as all other pho places were closed (I didn't realize until now that they usually close at 3 or 4 and then open again at 5pm). 

The items on the menu were mostly Vietnamese dishes (rice, vermicelli, noodles, pho) but also Chinese (chow mein). I guess they're trying to cater to the mixed crowd around 17th and Valencia. 

Prices were okay-ish (although they offer some starters for $10) - the pho was $9, and vermicelli vegetable dish $10. I liked the portion size which was generous, hence thumbs up for the value.

Would go back if in the Mission during odd hours.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Although decent for dining in, I can't recommend it for takeout. Portions were meager with my $13 entree, which was principally rice and left me still hungry.
author: JayBee L.

description: It is the worst food I never had to tasted in my life, order the wonton soup this is sooooo disgusting tastes old and ugly sap...I never ever in my life I would order food from this place anymore...
author: Wendy P.

description: This place is really good and consistent. A great go-to for a quick no-frills quality bite.
author: N. W.

description:
Well, it's a pho option on Valencia in the mission, i'll give it that. The decor is pretty nice as well; definitely not like some of the more hole-in-the-wall places in the tenderloin. It's also open on Sunday, which was convenient.

The downside of a place like this is that the prices are a little higher than places in less nice areas, like Evergreen or farther places in the tenderloin / chinatown. 

I picked up a combo pho here, and the broth was flavorful but more sweet than I was expecting. There was a good variety of beef parts, not just beef slices but also tripe and beef balls as well. Overall, great for a quick fix if you're close to valencia, but not really not worth making a trip for.
author: Alexander L.

description: Amazing prawn noodle soup and the spicy lemongrass chicken ...and extremely fresh food ...
author: Abhilasha S.

description: The food is awesome! But the customer service sucks!!!!! My coworkers eat here often i keep trying to give em a chance. And every time i do it's bad  the host he is soooo rude. Anytime we go we can sit anywhere in the shoebox. But this time he argued us down squeezing us at a 2 person table when we had others joining us!!!! Mind you it was only 1 other person in the restaurant
author: Oodles W.

description: Love this pho place in the Mission! It's clean, friendly and good food. Can't get much better than that for a Vietnamese restaurant!
author: Vanessa P.

description: Came here with a group of friends and we all loved it. We were all craving pho and this was a very solid pho place. Highly recommend. Most of us opted for the house special pho which comes with an assortment of meat. The large is quite large, but finishable. Food came out quite fast as well.
author: Vinny T.

description:
I was starving and walking down Valencia and found this spot.

I walked in and to the back to place a to go order takeout. They provided me with a menu and my order came out pretty quickly. Everyone else was sitting at small tables in this narrow space.

I got the seafood noodle soup which was really good. It came in a plastic to go container. The broth was separate from the seafood and vegetables so I could mix them together when I got home. Yum!
author: Rawlins R.

description: The pho here is so so. Soup base is not that good. Catfish in claypot was gross. Overly salty and just not the caramelized flavor I was looking for.
author: Ann L.

description: Nope. Sunflower is much better and with better service ( and now more space!) (had the veggie pho). Also, I recently checked out Mao and while it looks "less authentic" seems more solid with quality of meat/produce used (had the beef pho + extra veg).
author: Vicki T.

description:
I was in the mood for some Vietnamese food earlier this afternoon and Mau, Cha-Ya, and Sunflower were all closed. I've passed Than Tam 2 many times but had never ventured in to try it until today.

Ordered the Vermicelli Noodle dish w/ Pork and an Imperial Roll and a Longan drink. 

The bowl came with ~10 thin pieces of pork over a heaping mound of vermicelli, with cucumber underneath and shredded carrot and peanuts on top. The pork was very greasy and unappealing, the whole dish was a chore to eat.

The Longan drink was obviously from a can of the fruit in syrup, with maybe a little water added. Very sweet and generic tasting.

It was pretty disappointing to specifically want some fresh-tasting, nourishing food, and walk out feeling tired with acid reflux. Won't be back.
author: Megan D.

description: Thanh Tam II is a decent place for pho. I would recommend against getting the dry chicken noodles--weirdly flavored and too much peanut. The soups are better. I've definitely had better spring rolls too but it's not bad for the price. Also conveniently located with fairly quick service. The set up is a little tight and they don't want customers sitting too close to the door.
author: Lydia Z.

description: In another neighborhood, I'd give this place three stars, but most of the other dives in the Mission are so good that this level doesn't cut it. Food was fast but the beef in the vermicelli noodle bowl was tough and a little weird. Pork fried rice was greasy.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
The menu is extensive for authentic Vietnamese food. Friendly for first-time Vietnamese food-eaters with pictures on the menu that are accurate. I got the spring rolls as an appetizer which were very good. 

I've been craving pho for a while so I had the rare beef pho with added meatballs. The broth was decent but there was little meat and vegetables. Still pretty solid meal that satiated a good traditional Vietnamese pho with friendly and fast service!
author: Faith L.

description: In a nut shell: quick service, affordable, and plenty of options. Food was just greasy but still had some flavor. Would like to check out other places first.
author: Rob M.

description:
As recent tradition goes, my mom and I get pho together once or twice a month and chat about work / life / family / etc. On this Friday evening, we were attending an arts and improv night at church, which was a refreshing change up to the booziness and general debauchery I usually put myself through on Friday nights. So we stopped in at Thanh Tam II on Valencia as it's super close to our church. 

I've only dined at Thanh Tam II once, way back in the day, and I didn't really remember how cramped it is, but now I've noted this. We walked in to the restaurant to the shrill voice of a woman loudly and rapidly speaking Vietnamese, guessed at a place to sit, and began to browse the menu. 

I chose Thanh Tam out of the other locations in the area because I remembered that they have the option of thick noodles in their pho. Unfortunately, the only flat noodles they had were "old", per our waiter, and so they weren't an option. Why would you have old noodles? Just throw them away if that's the case, or, as a popular Mission restaurant, be stocked with the ingredients to one of your main dishes.

My mom, always the optomist, ordered a tofu salad and raved about it for the rest of the night. I got the Rare Steak Pho which was bland and had to be drowned with Sriracha, the jalapenos that were served alongside were old, or had been cut the previous day and were drying out and whiteish. When I went to use the restroom, I noticed all the Imperial rolls waiting on a tray to be fried, right next to the restroom, um, okay, yea, that seems sanitary. 

Finally, when our bill came, we noticed that the total was hiked up from what should have been $17.89, to $24.95. So I had to show our waiter and the shrill woman from earlier the error, which was corrected. Mistakes happen, I get it, but this was just such an unejoyable experience all around, I will surely not be bringing my dear mom, or our business back anytime soon.
author: Crystal C.

description:
One of the better Vietnamese restaurants in the city.  Fast service, no wait on a Saturday evening, and yummy food!

We ordered:

imperial rolls - which came with more pickled veggies than other places.  good crisp and flavor.

fried rice with shrimp - not too greasy, good flavor

pho - average, broth could be more flavorful

tofu salad - our favorite dish that we ordered, such a nice light and fresh tasting dish with mint and basil and grilled tofu

Not sure why this place doesn't have a higher rating!  Also looked like they have free delivery, so we definitely know what we're ordering next time.
author: Janel C.

description:
This place is awesome! Definitely the best Vietnamese food I have tried in San Francisco. 
The Shaken Beef and Vietnamese pancakes are a must! Shout out to Johnny and his warm and pleasant character that made us feel like home.
author: Boban V.

description:
On a stretch of Valencia where you can have pretty much any kind of food you want - hipster tacos, working-class Mexican, upscale French - this little, unassuming Vietnamese spot just doesn't stand a chance of staying in anyone's culinary memory. With Little Saigon just one BART station away, I would be hard pressed to make a return visit here based on what I tried on a lonely weeknight when I was perusing their fairly robust menu on a relatively busy evening. When hamstrung by indecision, I tend to go for the predictable and ordered the $6.75 Goi Cuon (Spring & Pork Rolls) (photo: http://bit.ly/1kli8ke).

It wasn't terrible but it wasn't very fresh-tasting either. The peanut sauce was its only saving grace. For my main dish, I went for the $9.95 large bowl of Pho Dac Biet (Special Combination Beef Noodle Soup) (photo: http://bit.ly/1huzzic). It contained all the right ingredients - the beef balls, the flank steak, even the tripe - but it was done in by the watery broth which didn't sustain any of the meaty flavor. Like ramen, pho is an artfully satisfying soup when properly executed, but when prepared with indifference, well, you can almost taste the shrug in every slurp. I'm sorry to say that the service matched the quality of the pho. Just not a memorable meal here.

FOOD - 2 stars...spring rolls taste flat but nothing compared to the pho
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...nothing too memorable about the space
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...nothing wrong with the speed but a sense of ennui surfaced
TOTAL - 2 stars...packing my bags and leaving for Little Saigon
author: Ed U.

description:
There are no places to eat pho in the Castro District so this was the default choice of restaurant that is walking distance. When my friend and I entered the restaurant, we were directed to sit at a table that had not been cleaned after the last customers. Luckily there were only dirty cups (and not half-eaten food) but that was super unwelcoming.

The waiter was quick to take our order and bring our food, but the food itself was mediocre. We ordered spring rolls and pho in beef broth. The spring rolls looked fine, but I can't put my finger on what was wrong with them. Maybe it was the dryness or the rubbery texture of the skin that did not taste fresh. The peanut sauce tasted starchy too.

The beef broth tasted artificial and I realized that maybe I should have tried the chicken broth instead. They actually give you a LOT of noodles and meat for a small size order, so that's the only awesome part of this restaurant. The beef was incredibly dry which made it difficult to eat. By the end, I was full but not satisfied. 

We had to flag down our waiter to get the bill and as soon as that was done, I made a dash for the door. I might come back because it's so close and open relatively late, but I'm better off traveling in the other direction towards the Sunset District.
author: Stefanie C.

description: If I could I would give this place 3.5 stars. I am rounding down to a 3 mainly because of service. Our waiter was very indifferent and ignored me several times when I tried to flag him down. I had to wait for 20 minutes to get him over to take our order and to ask us what we wanted to drink. I think that's an excessive amount of time to wait before the waiter comes over to introduce himself. I order the spring shrimp rolls and the combination soup with chicken broth. The shrimp rolls were good. The combination soup wasn't anything special, but not too terrible either. I wouldn't come back here because of the terrible service. I am usually quite lax and don't mind if the service is not the most hospitable, as long as they are decently quick and don't ignore me when I try to place my order and have to keep my arm in the air for 15 minutes.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Now that Sunflower's closed, where oh where will we get our hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese food?

What about right across the street?

Thanh Tam II is the epitome of hole-in-the-wall, right down to the dudes mixing condiments in the dining area and the torn up upholstery. Beef bowls are more lettuce than meat and it's not particularly fresh. Still, it works in a pinch.
author: Casey S.

description: Thanh tam is the restaurant I miss the most in SF. Going to get spicy lemon grass tofu for looking is one of my fondest memories. The space is small and the same 4 guys are always working. The food is garlicky and amazing.
author: Hendrix J.

description:
I have been looking for a Vietnamese place that uses the proper rice wrap for imperial rolls for 15 years! I have been sorely disappointed everytime. SF, The Peninsula, East Bay, everywhere I looked just to be saddened once again. I never thought I would find a place comparable to Tu Lan. I had pretty much given up! Boy, was I WRONG.

From the appetizers to the Pho nothing disappointed. Service was excellent! Calm atmosphere. I am ashamed that I must've passed by here a MILLION times in my hunt for food and NEVER saw it!

I spent so much of my 20's in this area drinking and carousing within the immediate vicinity and never knew what I was MISSING! Never again. My hats off to you Than Tam II. I now have 2 staple Vietnamese restaurants to go to depending on which I am closest to.

I am sick and asked the girl on the phone which soup would be best. I liked the hot spicy beef. She said a seafood combination is good too and that she could make it spicy. She even asked if I wanted some fresh squeezed OJ! I said yes and a ginger ale too. 

She almost didn't take my order for delivery because they are cash only usually. She made an exception for me. Thank you! She was so very sweet that she included a NOTE iside saying Feel Better with a smiley face! Awwww.... They win my business hands down. Way to go the extra mile for a sick girl. I LOVE you guys!
author: Stella T.

description: Ordered for pick up once and the food was decent. Decided to order delivery today. Apparently it is $25 min and cash only for delivery, which it doesn't say anywhere on their website. Instead of saying it nicely, the person I talked to on the phone started berating me for not ordering $25 worth of food. It's alright, I think I'll pass on this place in the future.
author: Kassi D.

description:
This is my go-to vietnamese when i'm in the mood for cheap and cheerful (inexpensive food that makes you feel good). I haven't tried everything, but I always get Imperial rolls (nom nom nom) and pho. I know Mau is right down the street, but if you're looking for something well priced, huge portions and no line, Thanh Tam is for you. 

Also they give you fortune cookies after, so there's that.
author: S W.

description:
Just ate here last night, and I think its the best vermicelli bowl I've every had. We ordered the lemon grass chicken vermicelli. The veggies were slightly cooked, so still a little crunch which I like.  Great taste and ample portion. Also, excellent spring rolls. The place is very authentic--looks like family run Vietnamese. Simple decor and clean.  Our new favorite place to go for very tasty and affordable Vietnamese food.  We had almost gone to another Vietnamese place down the street, but saw that it was trendy and run by non-Vietnamese. Didn't look authentic like this place.  

Was glad the TV wasn't on!  (especially since I didn't have my "TV Be-gone" device!)
author: Linda n.

description: The waiter should be given the rudest server award.  He wouldn't accept my order as requested despite citing food allergies, the accommodation was not out of this world and all other restaurants do accommodate me. I am never ever coming to this place.
author: Malena P.

description:
Unbelievable! Mother's Day lunch with my soon-to-be mother fiancé... When in the Mission we usually go to Mau. However, we opted to try Thanh Tam 2. What a mistake! 

When we entered, we decided to sit at a four top because it would be less cramped for my pregnant fiancé. Since it wasn't busy and all four tops were available. Right when we sat down the "Pho Nazi", the man working scolded us "NO!" and moved us to a two top. We reviewed the menus that were already placed on tables and we're ready to order. He was behind the counter and payed us no attention. The woman working with him was kind enough to bring us water but spoke no English so we had to wait for the man to order. 10 plus minutes later... Still no service; HORRIBLE!

I can't remember last time I got up in a restaurant and left. I'm usually pretty tolerant.  But when you're with a hungry pregnant woman on Mother's Day... this did it. We left. He said nothing, no apologies. 

Oh well, wouldn't recommend based solely on service and would never try again.  We're sticking to Mau. 

Happy Mother's Day to all the Moms out there!
author: Jason T.

description:
This little gem is my favorite vietnamese spot in the Mission. Everything on the menu is less than $12 and the food is solid! I enjoy eating various dishes from their Rice Plate menu and also their delicious wonton noodle soup with egg noodles (my fave!). 

Overall a very satisfying and easy choice if you're in the mood for a quick and affordable bite! Also, they are vegetarian friendly!
author: Kitty K.

description: Stumbled upon this place randomly and glad I did because the Pho Tai is so delicious. Perfectly done! I'm so picky when it comes to Pho Tai and constantly have to lower my expectations because there's so many variations but generally this is what it should taste like if done right. Service is very bad because there's only one person waiting on tables but I guess that's the trade off. Poor service for delicious pho broth.
author: Briget P.

description:
Deliciousness. One of my favorite vermicelli craving spots
Fresh, tasty and you dont have to wait long
author: Sherry B.

description: My boyfriend has always been a usual, but he put me onto this place for our "anniversary" lol. Now months later, everyone knows me better. Everyone you come with will be happy.
author: Tattiana B.

description: Came in here for lunch and ordered a big fat bowl of Pho Tai Sach which was the rare steak and beef tripe pho. $11.50 for the whole thing. It's huge and tasted really good.
author: Kenson K.

description: The Best Pho in SF! Been going here for years... Chicken is bomb fried rice is bomb. Everything is pretty darn good here. You won't be disappointed.
author: Rox N.

description: This review was for a couple weeks back. If I had yelp like I typically do to find a good spot to eat, I wouldn't have ended up here. However, a bunch of us hungover ladies were desperately in need for a cure and left it up to my lovely sissy to pick and she did the executive decision by choosing the closest pho place to us. Which sadly happened to be this one. Although.... when we were done with this place and walked a few doors down... there was an elegant pho restaurant called Mau that looked clean and inviting (yes, I was pissed). lol anyways, this place sucks. Really sucks. The pho is overly salty and it doesn't come with the usual garnishes: no basils! Only bean sprouts. Wth. The only plus was it came with a good amount of meat. My best friend got the bun bo hue, which is typically spicy, but stated there was zero spice + there was a hair in her soup! Also, I don't know if y'all feel weirded out by this, but they keep glasses of water pre-filled in the fridge. So when you come, they just grab one and serve it to you. Just the idea of fridge air all accumulated in my cup of water gives me a gaggy feel, especially with no ice. This restaurant feels really unsanitary, un-tasty, and unsatisfying to me. I wouldn't come back. Ever!
author: Kath N.

description: This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant . I have been coming here with my family for years and have always received excellent service.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
If I have to rate Thanh Tam II against its cohort in the city then maybe its a 3 but to compare it to the likes of the South bay or Orange County, this place deserve no more than a 1.   

After going through process of elimination based on proximity, yelp rating and previous experience, my colleagues and I narrow our list to Mau and Thanh Tam II.   

We end up opting for Thanh Tam II because it looks like a hole in a wall so we assumed that it would be more authentic. This could be it I thought to myself, no longer will I have to venture out to the south bay to satisfy my craving for pho. 

I was wrong. 
 
If one was to google pho, they will quickly come to the conclusion that it is a noodle soup with a beef broth. Emphasis on beef. That was clearly not the case with the Pho at Thanh Tam II. Not only was it lackluster in proportion of the round tip slice but the there was only a hint of beef in the broth for a soup known as "Beef noodle soup". 

I definitely do not recommend this place for pho. Stay clear.
author: Tim T.

description:
Pretty decent pho. It's expensive, but hey, you're in the Mission. If you want something different than burritos you gotta pay up, right? Usually they're pretty consistent, but the last time I went there, the broth wasn't flavorful enough.. it was kinda watery :( 

I'll still go back like every weekend though.
author: Angela L.

description:
Transported! 

Last night my friend and I were transported to Vietnam. I have been craving good pho for so long that I forgot I was craving it. When I sat to review the menu, I was eyeing some more delectable dinner entrees, but in the end I decided on the beef combination pho. Lawd help me! It was perfect. The broth was perfect, everything tasted amazing. 

The quail we started with? Perfectly fried. I always feel like a happy heathen eating small birds and then discarding a pile of bones onto my plate. These made me happy yesterday. So much yum.

It's funny, we were walking to Mau, of which I'm only a somewhat fan, when my friend said "Let's go here." It was another happy accident, and now I have a home for pho this winter in my neighborhood.
author: Justin S.

description:
I can never get enough Pho....when i need my fix this is my go to.
I love how quick the service is. Cheap eats.
The broth for the seafood soup is just right, more noodles than toppings and seafood which is the only draw back.
I always get either a soup, fried rolls or vermicelli. Never ventured out but those dishes work.
They've changed the layout a bit, so now they have new menus and pcitures up so you can see the plates.
It's a small space, so when they make fried food-you leave stinky.
author: francis c.

description:
This place is legit. I've come here on multiple occasions with friends. It's the best place to come to when you can't think of anywhere to go, or know exactly what you want to eat, but it'll  def. hit the spot.

It's likely that you've walked by this place on Valencia hundreds of times but never even knew it existed. That was the case for me. Once you step inside, it's seriously like you're in your Vietnamese best friend's parent's house. It's most def. a mom and pop type place.

Every time I come here I get the sliced BBQ pork, with fried rice, and fried egg. So good. Never fails. The pho and string beans are good here too. Service is pretty quick. All in all, for what you pay, and the satisfaction of the food, I'd say this place is a keeper in my rotation of go-to restaurants on the fly.
author: Shawn B.

description: One of the more authentic Vietnamese restaurants in the bay area. The beef broth is quite tasty and service is quick. Would like to see numbered menu items for efficiency in ordering. Overall I'm satisfied with this restaurant and will probably be back!
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
This is a very decent Vietnamese restaurant.  The service is good, you just have to be agressive about it. If you want to order politely wave. I saw some over privileged bros get offended for their lack of service but they were so rude!

The hot and sour soup was so good! I recommend getting a side of noodles or rice with it because it doesn't come with it. 

The sandwhiches were not the best. My bf ordered the chicken and pork while I got the tofu. The tofu sandwich was plain and not well seasoned. The bread tasted sour. I'd stick to their phos and bbq plates of I were you.
author: Julia Q.

description:
I've gone here for lunch and dinner and both are really delicious and the best price for a lot of food on Velencia. It's an intimate space and can get pretty crowded on the weekends for dinner, but that's pretty typical for anywhere on Velencia. The wait staff is attentive and the food comes out fast, but you don't feel rushed while you're in there.

What I like about this place is that you can tell it hasn't changed much. It's not giving into all of the yuppies that have bought up all of the property around it and it continues to have customers flowing into it. They haven't raised their prices so people who live in the area can still afford it and they've kept their dishes authentic. I've had their Ga Xao Dau Que (chicken with green beans) and a tofu bowl from their lunch menu, and both were really satisfying in flavor and portion.

Definitely go here and support the local restaurants!
author: Jacqui A.

description: Quick service, lots of vegetarian options.  I tried the vermicelli and vegetable chow fun dishes.  I wish they had hot oil--that would make the dishes scream with flavor!
author: Aeon N.

description:
Another restaurant that my company catered lunch from. 

We had some vietnamese sandwiches, as well as tofu vegetable noodle soup.

The noodle soup was pretty yummy. I like how they separated the soup from the noodles and ingredients so that by the time it was delivered, the ingredients and noodles were still fresh instead of soggy from being in the soup. 

The bahn mi was pretty good too, although it lacked some seasoning, which could be easily fixed with some hot sauce :)

Overall a decent meal!
author: Christina N.

description: After a bad experience with delivery, no longer going to patronize this restaurant.  I prefer the Vietnamese restaurants on Irving over this place.
author: michele g.

description:
I'd rather pay a few more bucks and go to Mau. The food here isn't bad, but significantly less satisfying in terms of flavor and quality of food. 

Spring rolls (2 stars): dry. 

Grilled pork and egg roll over rice (4 stars): this was the best thing we had. Good pork, but wish we had more of it. Egg roll was good albeit very greasy. 

Combination pho (2 stars): the broth was soooo bland. I had to put half a bottle of sriracha. Compared to Mau's ginger chicken broth, this was as if they just washed the chicken with the water. Yuck. Avoid!! 

I used to really like this place, but after getting spoiled by Mau I can't go back here. Disappointing.
author: Michelle K.

description: This place serves basic Vietnamese staples: pho (which they list as "broth"), bbq pork over rice (which comes with a nice fresh salad of cucumbers, carrots, lettuce & cilantro), classic imperial rolls. I opted for the imperial rolls (which they call "egg rolls)5 over vermicelli & sprouts. The rolls were great, but the fish sauce was weak--like watery. The salad needed more cilantro. Fortunately, they had sriracha chili sauce to brighten it up. The service is kinda lax, waiters pretty much ignore you. I ptefer Tu Lan on 6th & Market, but if you're in the Mission & you want a quick, affordable lunch, this is your spot.
author: Scott F.

description: One of the best delivery food spots EVER. Inexpensive, delicious, reliable, and fast. Their Vietnamese veggie pancake is amazing. Enjoy!
author: Emily L.

description: My wife is Vietnamese-American and this is the only place in SF that we can go to get authentic Vietnamese. Their pho, banh xeo, imperial rolls, rice plates - everything on the fantastic. Service is good and food is always ready fast, and never expensive.
author: Adam T.

description:
Had BBQ pork vermicelli and fresh spring rolls. Pretty decent food overall and at a good price. We did delivery and it was delivered pretty fast!

Will probably order here again!
author: David L.

description: The place was nearly full but they seated me right away. They were quick to wait on and check up on me. The vermicelli bowl with pork and egg roll was very good and very affordable.
author: Cotter R.

description: Went here for some pho and decided to get the combination pho (large) and bbq pork and shrimp noodles. The latter was kind of what you expected, nothing special and was fine. However, the pho was definitely disappointing. The bowl was big, but there wasn't much content in it. There wasn't a lot of meat, and it was chunky and not thinly sliced. The tripe was impossible to find since it was smaller than the noodles. The broth also seemed to be extremely diluted. Probably will not come back here for pho at least.
author: Victor D.

description: My New favorite Thai food place in San Fran. Can't believe I've never seen this place before. Their broccoli and shrimp with garlic sauce is out rages yummy. Deep fried egg rolls are the bomb. Family owned and run. Authentic and delicious!
author: Christine C.

description:
For when you need tripe in your pho! Look, this place isn't great but they are serving up solid food. Sure, there are better places, but if you are locked in the mission and need more authentic and less americanized, this is your place. It wins by default. Service is spotty. 

Mau is too hipstery. Jasmine Garden's new revamped menu is too simple. Thanh Tam is the place for all those cold weather cravings. Nothing spectacular but certainly fits the bill.
author: William V.

description:
With a legit Vietnamese restaurant a block away one would think they'd step up their game, but their take out service leaves much to be desired. If rice is a must, add it as a side and go a la cart for an additional dollar - I felt robbed looking at my 60% rice 40% tofu curry entree. Or bring Tupperware for them to put that rice in?? Hmmm

Their imperial rolls are still reliable!
author: eVa J.

description: Fresh veggies, tasty and refreshing. Will have to come back and try their sandwiches and noodle soups
author: tomohisa w.

description: Great spring rolls! Not overly packed with vermicelli noodles like some places. Sesame beef and brown rice plate is my go-to order. Not super fatty meat. Great with fish sauce. Favorite (not overpriced), authentic Vietnamese food spot in the Mission!
author: Lauren T.

description:
Worst service ever. Went today for lunch around 1:30 (2/7/15) with my partner. The moment we entered the restaurant, there was no greeting, no smile - just a grunting noise and finger pointing to a table from an older guy sitting at a table cutting basil leaves and TRANSFIXED to the TV. 

The restaurant wasn't even busy - only four tables were filled. We waited and waited and waited for a good eight minutes before we got any acknowledgement from the "server" who was also transfixed to the TV (there was an awful, cheesy Nick Nolte movie on). Our supposed server never said hello, never cracked a smile, didn't utter a single word to us. He solely took our food order and quickly went back to watching TV. He didn't even ask us if we needed something to drink! 

While the food was decent (we got tofu and mixed veggies, fried rice with fried eggs), the vibe was so weird. This is a family run restaurant where the family members would rather watch TV than acknowledge and provide service to customers. We were confused on whether to pay at the table or up front even though the check was dropped at the table. Do they even know what a smile is??? Are they mute? Is Nick Nolte more important than paying customers? 

Never going back. Note to the restaurant from someone who manages one, learn steps of service! It's apparent profits are declining here as many patrons are heading to Mau (which is my go to spot for Vietnamese food in the Mission). In the ever changing restaurant business, especially in the Mission, competition is fierce and Thanh Tham II isn't cutting it!!! PASS! And..TURN OFF THE DAMN TV!
author: Kim N.

description:
Pho-CK this place! I seriously considered walking out shortly after the meal was served; but held out on a hope and a dream that some part of the dining experience here would/could be salvaged. -- 2 stars for mediocre Vietnamese in the area (+1) and (+1) inexpensive prices. 

Minus stars because service would benefit greatly from better communication tactics.

The three bean drink is SALTY AF (-1) if something is sent back, listen to the reason why, ask whether customer wants a replacement or a write off the check, and communicate it to the cook.  To the cook (-1): don't send passive aggressive parting shots as the customer is settling up. I cannot stress enough how salty BOTH iterations were --there is still a burn in my mouth from where the liquid from the two sips (one from each drink) sat in my mouth. 

Also was pretty miffed that server did not allow us to sit at the end of a larger table, and away from the door as specifically requested (-1)-- and mere minutes later (before being served water) a group of two gets seated at near the front. I've been here plenty of times where larger tables had to be shared. 

I will not return anytime soon, and will speak poorly of it to my associates.
author: Alexander T.

description:
This place is great! It's been a MIssion institution since the early 90s. I've gone to so many Vietnamese restaurants in SF just trying to find some really good Pho (of which there are a few). Thanh Tam II is definitely in my top 3. 

* Great service
* Great food
* Great atmosphere

I will continue to go back! :)
author: Aaron B.

description:
The food is mediocre and the service sucks. The girl who sits up at the register is a classic example of someone who is way hotter in her head than she is in real life. I've been to this restaurant a few times now (not going back!) and she couldn't be less happy to be there - I'd feel sorry for her if she weren't such a jerk.

This isn't an expensive restaurant (~$10 for a small pho) but it's not a great deal either given the quality and quantity of food - super skimpy on the protein, flaccid veggies and even small portions of noodles. To compare, a Turtle Tower pho is well worth being a $35 dish if Thanh Tam's sad phos are selling for $10.
author: Janice J.

description:
Was in the area and randomly chose this place as i found a parking spot across the street. The restaurant is a bit cramped, with a whole row of tables running down 2 aisles.

I had the beef salad which I like.  The beef were very thinly sliced and was not fully cooked but not raw either. Kinda liked it that way. Not fully cooked.

 Got a bit dehydrated (probably due to the sugar  & sodium in the ngoc nam) and drank 3 glasses of water with it! I'd consider returning.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The only reason I got Vietnamese food in the Mission was because I was sick and wanted soup. This place seemed a bit more reasonably priced than the others, so we came here.

I got the rare beef pho. The veggies that came first were obviously not fresh. The second warning sign was how quickly the pho came out. It came out within 5 minutes of me ordering it. Way too fast for pho. Evidently not freshly made, most likely pre-made and just re-warmed. The broth was very bland and not impressive. The "rare beef" was not rare. I hate that they put it in the soup without asking me. Usually they ask if you want it on the side - and I always want it on the side. The fact that they put it in the soup before serving it to me completely defeated the "rare" purpose.

Was it inedible? No. But would I return for another try? Probably not.

There are way more choices in the area. Maybe not many more Vietnamese choices, but I rather go further for a better pho.
author: Junel S.

description: Ok space, less than amazing food. We had 2 different phos. The rare beef pho wasn't very flavorful and was all noodle, the spicy beef pho tasted almost like a canned soup. Both were really heavy on the noodles and the beef just wasn't of good quality at all.The portions are large and the prices are low, though. Service was fine.
author: Disco B.

description:
Delicious, simple, authentic. This is a true Vietnamese restaurant. It's not super fancy-fussy like other restaurants on gentrified Valencia - which holds its nice charm. 

Go here for their Pho Dac Biet (house special beef pho), Hu Thieu Ga (chicken noodle soup) and their simple casual atmosphere.
author: Tom T.

description:
Awesome place, cheap and authentic. My favourite Banh Mi sandwiches in town!

Apparently the veggie pancake was kinda boring but that's the worse I could say about the place.
author: Greg W.

description:
Thanh Tam II is a block from where I live and it took me over a year before I tried it out (to be fair there are a gazillion restaurants on that street). It's got these weird neon lights in front of it that makes it look like they're in the business of fortune telling instead of Vietnamese food.

The food wasn't that good - it wasn't horrible, but just not that good. You can tell the ingredients they use aren't really fresh.

The service is, in typical/authentic Asian restaurant fashion, pretty bad. I've been ignored repeatedly, and the waiter/owner was visibly annoyed when I asked him a question about a menu item. 

To be honest, I recommend going to Mau down the road instead. It's less authentic, but the quality of food and service are better. If you're willing to walk a little further, you can also hit up Jasmine Garden up around Church and Market.
author: Don L.

description:
I love the Pho, the Wonton soup is so good, the crispy noodles aren't too heavy but plenty filling and the egg rolls & potstickers are also delicious with a little crunch to them. 

I love a big bowl of soup with hearty veggies and fresh ingredients - Thanh Tam does it.
author: Autumn B.

description:
Ate here with my date the same night as the Academy Awards, walking from the Roxie on 16th, where we saw the whole show projected on the big screen. I remember getting Spicy Beef with Lemon Grass Noodles, and it was absolutely the best meal of the day. I have already been back!

Kind of low key, but very delicious, and that's all that matters.
author: Garett T.

description: Reasonable price and average quality! Does the job if you want to save and are not seeking for extraordinary food.
author: Solene L.

description: Had the bbq vermicelli bowl with chicken and egg rolls. It was pretty good. I should have asked for more sauce, but it was great overall. I'd like to try different their noodle bowls next time.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Went there to taste test for an upcoming event.  Indicated wanted to try certain items without getting the whole orders. Very accommodating. Since I had no idea how much food to order,
Johnny assisted us with the menu items and how much to order. Day of the event, the food arrived on time.  The large trays of foods were hot and ready to go. He brought us many different sauces to try for each item.  Each tray was plentiful. The guests loved it.
Very pleased with the service and the food we received.  I recommend this place
for lunch or dinner and catering.
author: wanda f.

description: Better than Mau.  Not the best Vietnamese in the city (PPQ FTW), but my go to spot in the mission.  The bun is very good (my usual order) and the pho is also good.  The man who works during lunch hour is always really sweet and get our order in a timely manner.  Sometimes you have to flag them down for the bill, but as far as i'm concerned, that's a a San Francisco problem, because almost every restaurant I ever go to is like that.... Can't really say for the pho, but bun here is WAY better than Mau's.
author: Caroline W.

description: Came here for lunch today, was tasty! Chose the BBQ Pork and Shrimp Vermicelli noodle bowl and Imperial roles. Roles came out crispy and hot with a dipping sauce and the noodle bowl had great taste and texture. Food is reasonably priced. Also noting that I really enjoy shrimp so definitely happy this restaurant didn't skimp on those. Overall a great meal. I'd eat here again.
author: Margarita R.

description:
Wow that lady is a bitch! 
She asked me what size I want for my noodle soup over the phone, and she got upset for me to ask her what size they have, she said "omg" I asked you what size you want, and rant about the menu, what a dumb ass, I cussed her out on the phone because she deserved that. Fuck this place, and I'm hungry!
author: JV Y.

description:
Food is only okay and I would probably come back if this place is the only open place in the hood when I am looking for food. So, that pretty much means never. 

Noodles are tasteless, egg roles are pretty nasty with dipping grease and beef is meh. The guy who took my order was pretty rude and probably hates what he is doing as much as he hates his customers.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
Not too many Vietnamese options in the Mission and after a long day of dim sum and walking me friends and I were craving something light. 

Ordered:

Spring roll - solid nothing special but yummy
I ordered the beef goi, crunchy and a large portion size. Celery threw me off though, celery in goi? Strange

Seating is tight and service is prompt.
author: Jade W.

description:
You live in the Mission.  You're hungover.  You want pho.

My test of good pho places is ordering the meat on the side and hoping I don't regret what it looks like when it's not masked by that delicious broth that they concoct in the back.  Thanh Tam delivered!  No sleepless nights having nightmares of sketchy meat here!  

I'm also a frequenter of their vermicelli bowls and they don't disappoint if you're not in the mood for something hot.
author: Kamila L.

description: I had just finished tanning for viatmin D and decided to get my vitamin P, er,  pho on here and boy was I surprised!  The broth was tasty and the beef balls exploded with flavor.  Not only that but when I asked they put the giants game on for me and I got to watch the Giants beat the cubs over a nice steamy bowl of beefy pho while basking in post tan euphoria.  I found my happy place!  I'm looking forward to coming back!
author: Theron L.

description: I eat here often. OFTEN. It's quick, cheap and good. It's usually about 80% full so it's busy but you'd never have to wait long for a table. The sir that works there knows my picky order and gets it right everytime. They take credit cards and the service is generally pretty fast. If you're craving viet food but don't have a lot of time or money then this is the place pho you.
author: Yuxuan N.

description:
Was positively surprised by warmth, cleanliness and good food. It look nothing like it from the outside. 
Best imperial rolls ($6.75) I've had. Simply delicious, not greasy at all and very light. 
Fresh spring rolls $6.75)  were good, freshly made, warm. The peanut butter sauce was perfect! 
Chicken Pho ($7.95) was somewhat disappointing, not enough chicken flavor, no richness, but it wasn't bad. 
Service was fast, attentive enough.
Free delivery in 1 mile radius.
author: Natasha S.

description: This has a nice selection on the menu for a neighborhood rest., but I don't plan to return after the last 3 visits. cigarette smoke always seems to comes from the kitchen and into the dining area. The waiter denied anyone was smoking. Please fix the ventilation so diners don't have to breath cigarette smoke with their meal.
author: Yelika D.

description: I always have great food here especially the spicy beef pho. Slow service so don't go when it's busy.
author: Lu C.

description:
Before visiting, I use to have to leave the Mission to find decent Pho. (I'm not a fan of sunflower, mau, or the lotus garden)

This is now my defacto place when I crave pho/Bon mi/vermicelli. It hasn't been perfect everytime, but it's been great more than not.

The broth is amazing and my favorite Pho tai is never dried out and overcooked. If I ever feel too lazy to leave the house delivery is super quick.
author: Dane M.

description: very good from service to meal. Got the combo meat in beef broth with rice noodle. And my only complaint is the quality of the beef (thick and cheap, I'm use to thin slices. ) I asked for no beef balls and he gladly left them out. The chicken was good and the tripe too. Taste of the soup was perfect before I added sriracha and hoisen sauce.  ILL BE BACK
author: Lauren F.

description: If I could give 0 stars I defiantly would. For starters the container was cracked at the bottom and burnt my leg. I told the owner that I was not pleased with my food because it taste freezer burnt and I asked to have the food remade the owner replied "I give you yo money back you no come back here you tell me my food no good" what the hell how do you tell a customer that? Would not recommend this place to my worst enemy!!!!!!!!
author: Carmina C.

description:
Thought babe and I would come here for a quick dinner before we catch a movie, but they have suuuuppper slow service here. 
After we sat down and got our menus, we spent a lot of effort to flag the waiter down for him to take our order since we've been sitting awhile. I noticed that the lady behind the cash register can see us trying to get someones attention, but she made no acknowledgments nor try to tell another worker to come to our attention. So we waited... till someone finally came. 

And the food also took a while took, so we ended up asking them to just box our food to go, because we had to get to our showtime. 

I ate a few bites in the car ride and food was average. Oh yes, I had the pork chop rice, and babe had the pork chop rice combo thing. 

Not quite impressed with this place. Not sure if there will be a next time.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Very good Chicken Pho, light broth, nice sliced chicken breast, roasted shallots add nice layer of flavor 

BUT, is it worth $11 (with tax) before tip? No. There isn't a bowl of chicken pho in the world worth that price. Let alone, a bowl that is filled only barely halfway with the broth. I was nowhere near satisfied or full.  I'm coming from Seattle, where a gigantic MSG free bowl of chicken pho costs $6 at most.
author: Earls C.

description: Got veggie pho from here the other night, was pretty delicious! Enjoyed that it came with fresh tofu, broth was delicious large size was huge portion. I would eat their pho again!
author: Coco J.

description: Pho was decent; I ordered the #42, so it was pretty simple. Kind of expensive for a medium, $9+, but they did provide a lot of noodles. They don't have a lot of condiments like what I'm used to in Sacramento, so it felt like it was missing something. I had a bite of the curry chicken and lemon chicken, they were both good. Service was A-OK. Bathroom was only one stall in the back of the restaurant and it's a bit cramped in there overall, but the food is good
author: Nani V.

description: Very impressed by this place, both for the pho (quantify and quality), the imperial roll and the grilled pork. very cute casual date spot for a midweek meet up or just catching up with a friend. tables are TINY though, so if you get a big bowl of pho, be prepared to carefully feng shui the hell out of your table when other courses arrive!
author: Mike V.

description:
Here's the thing. I spent 9 days in the middle of a desert and after all that, I'm sick of eating steak, bacon (I know, I know shut up) and beef jerky. I was craving Asian food like mutha and the thing I wanted most was pho.

Although I was told Thanh Tam was better for bun, I had to have some noodle soup. I'm not a pho ga lover (unless it's TT) so I said surprise me. Brought back for me was a large pho dac biet (special combo.. all the goodies! you know, rare steak, tendon, tripe, beef balls etc). Cac dam even for take out it was pretty big. I couldn't finish it. They definitely don't skimp with the meat. This may sound weird, but I liked the fact that they boxed up the noodles in a clear ,flat take out container as opposed to most Viet places that will squash your noodles into a Chinese take out box. Why does this even matter? Well my noodles didn't end up sticking upright in a cube formation, that's why! 
Standard condiments were given, basil, bean sprouts, sliced jalapenos, lime, etc. I don't know if it was just because I just came back from the desert or something but the broth was extremely satisfying on its own (without the noodles). 

Split an order of cha gio. Decent, but I felt it should have been a little crispier. Also, the nuoc mam was on the sweeter side, but still slightly bland. I prefer it a bit saltier.. 

It's Vietnamese food in the Mission, have low expectations.
author: Susy C.

description: Stumbled onto this place on my way to meet some friends for ice cream at Bi-Rite. My name is Thanh Tam so of course I had to try it. Ordered a banh mi, or Vietnamese sandwich. It was a little more pricey than what i'm used to (I'm from sacramento) but it turned out to be perfect banh mi. The bread was crunchy, the meat was well seasoned and generous, and the veggies were fresh. Must now find the original Thanh Tam restaurant to try.
author: Teresa B.

description:
(See pics)

Review #1025.

This is an excellent Vietnamese joint with very delicious banh xeo (egg pancake), really good chewy rice on beef and egg rolls, delicious clay pot, very good pho, and very strong sharp Vietnamese iced coffee.

A place I dream of and will go there even it's not super close by me.

I do like this place better than Sunflower(s) across the street because of the dishes are more flavorful.

Service was also pretty good and without a sign standing outside, it's easy to miss.
author: T L.

description: Update from my June review regarding food poisoning from Thanh Tam: my housemate filed a complaint with the SF Department of Public Health, and we are not the only case of food poisoning from this establishment.
author: Yea A.

description:
I already forgotten this place.. It is pure clean inside,but the BBQ chicken was not tasteful as you see on the menu..
Most Vietnamese that I've eaten are on the good side.... Their  chicken was plain and tasted old.. Not for me...
author: Pedro D.

description:
Personally I think they have the some of the best grilled pork Banh mi in the city, though they do have their off days. Also, there is almost never a wait to be seated.

But pretty much all I get here is the sandwiches.
author: Ben H.

description: My go to banh mi (Vietnamese sub sandwich) place in the Mission. Best value for under $6. And will separate out be veg from the rest of the sandwich if you want to rebuild it for a later treat.
author: Judy L.

description: We got a delivery order from them last night and were super happy!  Our order arrived at our front door 25 minutes from when we called it in, which was quite fast.  (We do live a few blocks away.). The spicy lemon grass chicken and tofu with vegetables were both delicious!  We also liked the sweet corn chicken soup.  This may very well become our go to spot for delivery!
author: Barnali D.

description:
So a friend and I stepped in here tonight because we took a look at the menu, liked what we saw, and the prices were good. He got a sandwich and I got the beef, egg roll, and noodle bowl. The food was alright, though mine was lukewarm by the time it got to me. That surprised me because as I saw other people being served, their bowls were steaming hot. Maybe I just don't know that much about Vietnamese food.

Anyway, the prices were pretty groovy. Very affordable, as our check came to just under $15 for two people. The food was okay... Not a huge motivator to come back, but I would like to try a couple of their soups as the weather gets colder. I liked the ambiance. It's a small restaurant, tastefully decorated, though it did get a little loud as the seats filled up.

Service was "eh." The guy took our order promptly, and refilled our water glasses a couple of times, but we waited and waited to get the check. My friend actually had to flag him down after we'd sat there for about ten minutes after finishing our meal.

One really unfortunate thing about tonight, though, was a breeze coming from the back of the restaurant towards the front door. That draft carried smoke from the kitchen, which should have been carried off by the vent over the cook top, into the restaurant. It was a really unpleasant smell for me, and before long I had a throbbing headache from it.

I might go back, but it's not a place I'd really recommend.
author: Adam K.

description: Delivery ordering here is a mess. They never deliver in the time they commit to. And prices conveniently change every time I've ordered the exact same items. Oh well. Plenty of other Vietnamese options in SF.
author: Anil C.

description:
Not bad. There is nothing about this place that really jumps out as being excellent or standout good to me. I wouldn't say the food is bad here either.

There are plenty of other places in SF that I'd say are better. Whenever we are hungry for vietnamese this place never really jumps out.

Maybe I'll try so more different things on the menu.

Yeah...
author: Mario W.

description:
Stopped by while heading home to pick up some viet food to-go. I didn't want to go to Sunflower so we decided to try this place out. Plus - they are actually Vietnamese here (unlike the aforementioned place). Minus - the food is sub par. Our nuoc mam was on the salty side (it's usually the opposite, as it's typically made with sugar), the thit nuong (grilled pork) wasn't too bad but nothing to rave about, and the pho was just ok.

Prices are comparable to Sunflower, so if I had to choose between the 2 in the area, I'd probably go with the former based on proximity to me.
author: Johanna L.

description: Echoing some of the other reviewers, I recommend you steer clear of Thanh Tam II. I ate here on Sunday and lost three days of my life to food poisoning. The suspect condition of the kitchen and back area should've clued me in on my impending doom (you pass these on your way to the restroom in the back of the restaurant). I ate the pork & egg roll vermicelli and some of the fried wontons. It's hard to say exactly which one did me in, but it wasn't worth being tethered to the bathroom for three days.
author: Ben G.

description: Great value for what you get. Their regular steak pho is terrific. And their pricing and portions are terrific!
author: Charles T.

description:
Good menu choices with decent food and prices. Nothing really WOWED me about this place which is why its 3 stars. It should be 3.5 because the place is really reasonable for the food quality. 
The place is small, cramped, and kinda loud. Could be done way better and yet same time in the Mission so could have been way worse. The service is OK. I would go here again and for sure grab it as take out or delivery. 
The pho is great, the grill is too. The food in general is great to share and really its all under $10 a dish pretty much.
author: Natasha M.

description:
The CLASSIC CUTS (a poem):

They call me "Da Cutz", no not like the "Butcher"
Butchers cut meat, "Da Cutz" begs to differ
Quicker than termites that cut through your home
And sharp like the dark that'll pierce thru your soul
Yell "Cut" to signify the acting is done
As night ends the day where new day has begun
And since you'll find me in the cut more often than not
Let's go down the list of cuts just in case you forgot:

The front lawn? "I cut that"
Basketball defense? "I cut that"
Time for class? "I cut that" 
The cheese? "Yea, I cut that all the time man!"

I am always one to cut against the grain. So tho many have told tales of the Pho at Thanh Tam II, for me the grilled pork reigns supreme. Hence...the CLASSIC CUTS.

When having Pho, the broth is so important; it flavors everything in bowl. But this broth lacks richness. The rice noodles are limpy and lack elasticity.

The tender grilled pork is well marbled, juicy, thin cut, and cooked to perfection (much like the cuts in Vietnam!) The egg rolls are crisp and filling. Go easy on the fish sauce as it can get really salty really fast.
author: Robin H.

description: Had a stroll around the late dinner evening time with the love one, and decided to have some Pho. It was about 30 mins before closing time but felt we can work in the meal and leave before the proverbial "we need to go home, hurry up" service. Anyways, we ordered the Pho Bowls and they were decent. Nothing stood out, just the basic Vietnamese recipe meal. I don't drink alcohol nor soda, just plain old water. For some reason, the water tasted God awful. I took one strong sip, and I as done. I understand tap water is the default for most restaurants, however, this was some questionable water. It was cloudy, it was tasted really really really bad. Overall the experience was average.
author: Heather R.

description:
I'm still looking for a go-to Vietnamese spot in the Mission. This isn't it.

I went here with a large group. No one seemed overly enthused about their food. I had spring rolls, which were fine but not very flavorful. My entree was the Vietnamese pancake/crepe. It looked beautiful and had a nice, crispy texture--but again, it was just kind of bland and over-reliant on bean sprouts, which are great for crunch but not as the primary flavor profile.

The server didn't write down the orders and a got a couple things wrong. [An aside: it does *not* impress me when waiters don't write things down. Is this some kind of baller feat to show off their memories? Invariably, they get something wrong.] The server also was on the dour side. He does get points for not laughing when someone at our table asked for "whole wheat rice." [He meant brown rice.]

Another group rolled into the restaurant and it got extremely loud, we all had to shout to be heard. It also smelled very smoky in there.

All in all, not the most pleasant dining experience.
author: Elinor A.

description: Food is mediocre for a Vietnamese food. Guy who served me never smiled, I feel like he never liked me to be here thus my taste bud wasn't happy that made the good 1 star. Mix feeling if I will go back here. I miss Sunflower Restaurant, glad Tu-Lan reopened. There's hope!
author: Mann E.

description: Your typical Vietnamese hole in the wall, where service isn't necessarily great but then the food comes out and it makes up for everything. Pho is simple but delicious and the imperial rolls are deep fried yumminess, and they're big. Everything on the menu is worth a try, and the pho will bring you back to life after a long night of partying or a nasty cold!
author: Carmen M.

description:
One star for their customer service for food delivery. 
They are horrible on the phone. They yelled at me when I was trying to place an order, complaining that I was too slow. Also they are reluctant to take credit cards but it says they will on Yelp.
author: Hugh G.

description:
This is a case where a 3.5 would come in handy. Totally serviceable and tasty pho. Veggie pho comes in chicken broth tho so heads up.  They brought cilantro instead is basil, too, but gave me some when I asked. 

Quick service, hit the spot.  Nothing mind blowing but not bad at all.
author: David S.

description:
I've been here with my girlfriend twice now. The first time I had the grilled pork and fried spring roll vermicelli dish, and the second time I had the beef ball pho. My girlfriend had the rare flank steak pho both times, and both times we had the shrimp and pork spring roll appetizer.

Spring Roll Appetizer - Plump, fresh, and delicious. Really satisfying spring rolls served with a typical peanut sauce on the side. A good appetizer for two, or a nice light appetizer for four (with two decently sized spring rolls cut in half).

Pork and Fried Spring Roll Vermicelli - One of my favorite "Pho restaurant" dishes. Yummy grilled pork, and crunchy rolls. Hard to mess up, really. This one did not disappoint.

Pho dishes (Beef Ball and Rare Beef) - Not the best Pho I've had, but the price is right. Broth may be a bit on the sweet side for some, but I found it to be flavorful. Really hit the spot. I'd say the rare beef version is the superior dish. We've only tried the "medium" size (there is also a large version), but it was more than enough food for one person.
