Atmosphere - The first time we visited it was cramped and smokey (from the BBQ in the kitchen), but was kind of a fun atmosphere because of it. The second time was a quiet Saturday afternoon with barely anyone else in the restaurant. A very small establishment.

Service - Average. Had to flag down a server behind the counter for refills, but that's about the worst we could say. Wait staff is friendly. Kinda adds to the very laid-back atmosphere.

Overall, I could see myself returning to this restaurant once again. You can get a nice bowl of food and a drink for around $10. Very convenient, walking distance from BART.
author: Luke G.

description: The food is good! The delivery estimated time sucks. Waited 1.5 hours for pho delivery. No calls to let me know and vet poor customer service. When I called to check in on the status one lady was so quick to get me off the phone. Rude.
author: Rena D.

description:
We came here for a work lunch with 4 of us.

I got the spicy chicken with lemongrass noodle dish. Tons of flavor, very good chicken, and fresh veggies as well. The service is fast. 

Also tried the eggplant and rice dish - highly recommend for vegetarian, eggplant lovers. The eggplant was not too saucy.

The bahn mi sandwiches are a great bang for your buck. Seasoned great (I tried the chicken) and big for like 5-6 bucks
author: Harmony P.

description:
I went in after work for a bowl of pho.  I ordered a pho with rare steak and beef balls.  The pho came out quickly.  I counted 3 pieces of rare steak, and 3 half-pieces of beef balls (or 1.5 beef balls).

The broth was extremely watery.  It was readily apparent that the broth was watered down, either deliberately (to save effort and cost) or inadvertently (by adding too much water during the cooking process).  I could taste nearly no meaty flavor.

I quickly gestured to a waiter, a middle-aged Vietnamese gentlemen.  I asked him why the broth was so watery today.  The waiter's face went through an odd series of pained contortions as he stuttered out:  "I don't know.  Like that every day."  He quickly walked away.

At the cashier, I said, somewhat loudly, "the pho broth was very watery today.  What happened?"  The cashier looked at me.  We locked eyes.  He said nothing, and he looked down as he continued to count money to give me my change.  He then handed the change to me without a word.  I wish I were exaggerating.  Sadly, no.

Never going back.
author: James T.

description:
Best Pho I've had in the Mission.  Defiantly better then Sunflower.  Broth had a great flavor and their was a ton of noodles.

My girlfriend had beef over rice and it was really good as well.

Price was right and the service and decor where fine.
author: Jason S.

description: These guys are my go-to place for delivery when I'm not feeling awesome and just want some warm soup. I *love* the pho broth. I usually get the special combo pho but the beef balls are my favorite. And they deliver pretty quickly (when they're not too busy). I've been eating here for years and they are consistently awesome.
author: Kathy A.

description: Had the pho with beef tripe and steak and it was good. Wish there were more noodles and especially more beef because they are expensive. I wouldn't recommend this place unless as a last resort...
author: Edwin C.

description: Don't put three colored drink on your menu, when you don't even serve it. Quit playing games with my heart. Stop frontin'. Otherwise your food is good, too.
author: Zooey I.

description: Like to come here for some super cheap gritty vietnamese and chinese food.  Not the best pho in town, but for only $5-7 you can get a plate of chow fun or stir fried eggplant dish.  Also, there's usually no wait.  Has sort of a weird led light atmosphere that actually reminds me of restaurants in vietnam.
author: Aaron W.

description: Wandering around the mission looking for a place to eat is like wandering around a candy store looking for some sugar. It can be highly disorienting but rewarding. On a whim, we ended up at this place, and I was happy we did. I got the rare beef and beef ball pho, and my wife got one of the grilled pork rice dishes. Both were pretty tasty and good portions. Nothing that will really be burned into your memory, but pretty good Vietnamese at a decent price. I'm sure there are other good places around, but if you end up here, you'll be allright.
author: Brent W.

description:
Thanh Tam! I'm in amore with you. 

Egg rolls, spring rolls are a little over priced but I get here for the pho almost on the daily.

Why I love the beef pho(pho tai):
1.Good clean broth, always hot enough to cook the meat.
2.Noodles al-dente to perfection, doesn't bloat up too bad.
3.Consistency.
4.Nice people.

I like the atmosphere, and the ease of access.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Amazing rare beef pho. Great flavor and good amount of everything. My friend got the grilled beef with egg roll & noodles and it was awesome. Would definitely come back to try that beef on the sandwich. 4 stars for service. Wasn't really even existing tonight. Maybe it's normal but I'd still come back despite that.
author: Jess B.

description:
This place is a let down. How can someone have such a prime real estate for a restaurant and serve crappy food? Valencia st is a prime real estate because of so much competition, restaurants here are always on top of their game. Unfortunately, not for this restaurant. This restaurant is pretty much a let down. If you are in the mood for vietnamese, there is so much good restaurant around the city besides this one. But if you are in the mood for vietnamese and happened to be on Valencia St without any means of transportation then I say, better changed that mood to Mexican. 

And why do I dislike this restaurant so much? You may ask.. well the food was so salty. The only things that I liked here was their beverage - Thai iced tea... The crab and asparagus soup tasted like it has been sitting at the kitchen for days and lastly when they say grilled meat, they smother it with salt. I left the restaurant with a stomach ache and thirst for water due to all the msg or salt. This is the reason why I am giving this establishment a 2 star.
author: J C.

description: This place is pretty bad. Corn starch supreme. Not sure how they call it Vietnamese as tastes like bad Chinese. Staff is nice that's about it
author: andrew s.

description:
As we live a couple of blocks away and stroll the "Valencia corridor" almost daily, I've noticed Thanh Tam many times.  This Saturday night, my husband felt like take out and I felt like Vietnamese so we tried it.  And for pretty cheap, take-out food, I think Thanh Tam is damn good!  

We both had vermicelli noodles with roast pork and imperial rolls-- standard order.  The pork was really flavorful and not too chewy.  The imperial rolls were delicious AND didn't give me indigestion (I'm looking at you, Tu Lan).  We also had spring rolls, which were ok-- clearly made several hours before, the skins were a little tough.  

Can't speak to the quality of service (although other Yelpers seem unimpressed), but we will absolutely add this place to our regular take-out rotation (which currently includes Taqueria Cancun, Yamo, and occasionally Mission Chinese Food for interested parties).
author: Kristin P.

description:
This is the kind of place my Wonder Twin & I can come back to again & again. Decor is uncheesy, chairs are not rickety, tables are clean & new. We like those (seemingly unimportant) details. 

For $24, the two of us had dinner here Saturday night. Edibles:
-- imperial rolls: they do not mess around! Crispy, bubbly wrappers chock-full of pork. Probably some of the best I've had. Not too greasy=major plus. 
-- wonton soup w/ rice noodles (vermicelli): loved the chicken broth, tasted very light & clean. Baby bok choy was crunchy. Noodles were plentiful. Pork & shrimp won tons were okay, meaning it didn't taste the way I'm used to...a little more firm & had less shrimp than I'm used to. Okay, nonetheless. 
-- Wonder Twin got BBQ chicken over rice & we had a long discussion about how well they prep their chicken & only serve lean, appetizing-looking pieces. I'd definitely order that based on looks alone. 

Warm, cozy atmosphere (like you're being hugged!) Attentive servers. No MSG-induced headache. Easily five stars.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
What a great place! Great food, although I could stand a bit more spice. It's a perfect 1 $ restaurant. Fairly un-yupfied and no zagat's sign! Yea! The food is down home style.
My buddy had 5 spice chicken, done perfectly! The dish I had was shrimp and vegetables. The brown rice was as good as b' rice gets. Good portions, good prices, good people. EAT THERE
author: Richard W.

description: I don't know why this spot only has 3.5 stars.  I've tried all the Vietnamese spots in the Mission, and this is by far the best.  Awesome service once you get to know the people working.  Amazing food, very affordable.
author: Van P.

description:
Solid vietnamese food. The pho is not quite as good as at nearby Sunflower, but everything else is comparable and it's less expensive. Also, the banh mi is quite good.

Watch out for the dangerously low health inspection score -- according to health records (available on Yelp) the latest routine inspection found a "high risk vermin infestation" and lots of other health code violations.
author: David C.

description:
This is as good as it gets from a cheap eats vietnamese style.
Pho was legit, so was the Bun. I couldn't ask for anything more.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Ordered delivery from Thanh Tam II for Beef Pho and Grilled 5 spice chicken and rice. Delivery time was about an hour. The pho beef broth left much to be desired. It was watery and did not have much flavor. I had to douse the broth with Sriracha to pull the flavors out. Grilled 5 spice chicken was better than the pho. 

I would order again only because this is one of the only pho places that deliver to me. But would definitely stay away from the pho.
author: S P.

description:
This place is a nice alternative to Sunflower.  HOWEVER, if you're a vegetarian in search of pho, don't bother.

I had two bizarre experiences here regarding their vegetarian pho.  First, I noticed that their menu had a "tofu and vegetable" pho, but it only came with chicken broth.  I asked the waitress if they had an option with vegetarian broth, and she said yes but told me that if I wanted it, I had to order a large.  When I asked for an explanation of this unusual rule, she said, "That's just the way it is."  When I asked, "But why???", she just repeated herself and gave me a look that made it clear she really could not care less.  I knew I wouldn't get anywhere trying to negotiate, so I just ordered the large.  It tasted fine.

In the second encounter, I called to order the veggie pho for takeout.  The guy on the phone didn't impose the bizarre "large only" rule, but he did say, "You know our vegetable broth comes from a can, right?"  Uh, no, I didn't know that.  I ordered it anyway out of hunger and desperation.  Although the broth surely came from a can the previous time I ate it, somehow the knowledge of the canned broth made it taste like crap to me.  

I guess if you don't care about canned broth and/or being subject to tyrannical rules regarding the size of your pho, then order it.  Otherwise stick to the banh mi and spring rolls.
author: Mara E.

description:
Alright prices. 

Service wasn't complainable until it came to waters. Took a while for refills.

Food was tasty. We got the garlic eggplant with tofu added, no problem. Also a mixed vegetable plate that I don't remember the name of. Both were served with white rice. No option of brown rice that I saw.

Pretty okay.
author: Melanie P.

description:
After reading some of the reviews I thought I might offer my opinion.
Had very little exposure to Vietnamese food. Lived in the mission for over five years and often pass by this restaurant...not much to look at but the food was remarkable! (The foods that I tried, I haven't tried the entire menu).

The quail is delicious; all of their soups are extremely flavorful and just plain tasty (better on a cold San Francisco night).
The crispy Style Chow Mein was very nice and crispy. (plenty to share with two people, if you are watching your weight, as I am).
The Grilled Beef and Egg roll noodle was very different to any other noodle dish that I've tried. It was flavorful, aromatic and a delight. (again, plenty for two)

Now, don't think their food is design to dazzle you visually (in my opinion)...and their restaurant front isn't very inviting. But my grandmother would tell your to f...k yourself if that is only reason why you didn't try a place. Haha
Sure, some of you will find some dishes that you are not use to, like me, and a lot of the reviews are right, their customer service needs work. But if your first visit was not a pleasant one I invite you to try some of the dishes that I suggested. Now I find myself going to this place often. 

Two weeks ago it was freezing and I was feeling sick....on my way home I picked up their wonton soup and I couldn't help but to smile as I stuffed my mouth with this aromatic elixir.  Woke up feeling like running around Dolores Park! MAGICAL ...  (I hate running) lol
author: Ruben B.

description: Good Vietnamese food in the MISSION! score! The soup is delish, the servers are friendly and remember to fill up your water. We are some thirsty people! Thank you! Will be back for sure.
author: Sharon N.

description: I've never been here but this above review makes me think I'll refrain from going. I hate food poisoning! Eek! Methinks not.
author: Tom K.

description:
Across the street from Sunflower, where the crowds pour out into the street, even in rainy weather, this little Mission gem is one of the best kept secrets for no way, better-than-Sunflower, Vietnamese food. 

I recommend the Lemongrass Tofu and the Vem bowls!
author: Nicole d.

description: Hidden gem in the mission. Hands down best beef pho. Shrimp chow mein came out pipping hot and was some of the best I've ever had. Service - impeccable! Treat yo self - eat here!
author: Kathleen O.

description:
Hot Thursday at 5pm in the mission. I've got an hour to kill before a cooking class. I'm starved. I'm low energy.

Bahn me for $5 with a Vietnamese iced coffee for $2.75? Heaven. 

Quiet spot, but then again it is early and I'm dining solo. Fast service. Clean spot. 4 sauces to pick from to heat up my sandwich. Fresh cilantro and carrots. The chicken was similar to teriyaki chicken, but I'm not well versed in this cuisine. All I know is that it was tasty. If I lived near by I'd definitely explore the rest of the menu.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: My friend took me here one day.  She said she liked "Tofu Lemon Glass over Vermicelli" so I tried.  I really loved it!!  its soy-sauce based sauce is excellent.  I can have every day!  I've been here only 4 times and had it 3 times.  I also tried their hot and sour soup too.  It's a bit different than the Chinese one but I like theirs more.  Oh, another important thing is their dishes are reasonable.  I'm excited to try other dishes!!!
author: Mike M.

description:
This place is quieter and cleaner than Sunflower.

The garlic noodles aren't very greasy and the pho was fresh and delicious.

Go here if you want Vietnamese but want to skip the crowded, dive-y, louder Sunflower.
author: Shawn C.

description:
It ain't fancy. Or pricey. It's easy and consistently A-OK. 

I don't know why anyone seeing it from the outside (or the inside for that matter), or looking at just the font and layout of the menu, would expect it to be anything more than A-OK or be disappointed by what they ate here. 

It's like a greasy-spoon diner, but for Vietnamese food. Capiche?
author: Will R.

description:
I love both Sunflower and Thanh Tam II, but for entirely different reasons.

Thanh Tam II wins in the soup category.  Their pho broth is tastier and their Vietnamese hot and sour soup with fish is very good.  I can't say that it's the best I've ever had, but it is the best on Valencia St.

It's really good for lunch because it's usually empty and fast.  I can get in and back to work within 30 minutes.

I've heard of people feeling unwell after eating here, but it's usually a feeling of giddiness, euphoria and a little stomach upset, not your typical food poisoning.
author: D. K.

description:
I've come here multiple times before and each time the shrimp pho has the right consistency between broth, noodles, vegetables and shrimp. Their vegetarian spring rolls are great as are the deep fried prawn in rice paper wrap. 

The boyfriend likes their meatball pho and they've always had great consistency in flavor in that as well. Generally it's busy, but service is always great, prices are decent and they deliver, which for San Francisco this is a steal! 

Minus one star because of two things: 1. Once the let the door open and an uninvited bum came in which then the owner had to come out and asked him to leave. 2. Agreeing with Cyn W's comment, their cleaning solution for the tables is potent for such a small restaurant, but the food and convenient location is worth the stop.
author: Carolina S.

description:
It isn't that my first experience wasn't a wonderful one, it's that it was the first Vietnamese restaurant experience where Pho was not involved in about 2 decades.
The Banh Xeo was good, but since that time I've gone to at least 5 other places, 2 this week.  The bahn xeo tastes good, but the inside is kinda mushy.  What I was looking for was crisp on the outside and cooked on the inside.  Also the bean spourts though tasty, needed a little cook time.  I guess the assumption is they cook inside the crepe, but they didn't.  I've had delivery and they are nice, but food not great.
The restaurant is good, the staff friendly, but the food is not the best around.  I will order from here again, but not the best around.
author: Heather S.

description:
Let's be honest, here. I'm from Boston. Pho is pretty much Campbell's there. 

Still, I thought the chicken noodle soup I had was pretty amazing. The chicken was perfectly sliced and cooked, the broth had the right amount of tang, and the service was incredibly fast. I don't think I've been served that fast in my life. I'm totally okay with that.

Also, I left my credit card there, and the waiter ran after me. Major bonus points for that.
author: Maria D.

description: Omg was craving pho so badly today but don't want to drive 30 mins to our usual spot. Opened yelp to help me locate the closest pho joint and this was the closest place. It only had 3.5 stars and usually I don't go for restaurants under 4 stars. Today I realize I've been yelping wrong my whole life. Dude this place is amazing. I don't understand why it only have 3.5 stars. Each savory bite hits the spot so hard I almost got bruised. Their soup is perfect. The pho doesn't have that strong ricey taste. Best of all, the meat flank was soooooo tender and yummy! I am going to make this my new spot now. Nice and close to home and DELICIOUS! It is very clean too! Unlike most authentic Vietnamese restaurant haha.
author: Yaboo Y.

description: Really good rare Steak Pho. Very inexpensive, probably best Pho in and around the district.
author: Nik M.

description: Such a cozy, simple and fast place to get pho.
author: Dolores Y.

description: Pho was okay; not mind-blowing or cheap by any means but a good Vietnamese spot in the Mission.
author: Xteethx B.

description:
Nothing beats a hot bowl of pho on a cold/rainy day, or really any time one has a craving.

This place is a little pricer than I'm used to for pho, about $8-9 for a medium size bowl. The broth is good, but a little oily, however if you're craving pho and you're in The  Mission, this place does the trick.
author: Shira O.

description: The pho was meh. Should have held out for Turtle Tower.
author: Jess C.

description: My favorite restaurant hands down. Great family owned Vietnamese in the Mission - I go there about once a week and never get tired of the shrimp sugar cane wrap and lemon grass tofu.
author: Rita C.

description:
Last week, some friends and I stumbled upon this place while trying to find a place to eat dinner (after learning our go-to Vietnamese place was closed). 

We walked in and were seated almost immediately. We ordered a round of Sapporo's and the Vietnamese pancakes (banh xeo) to start. The pancakes were interesting, in a good way, lots of flavors and textures going on. We didn't realize they had meat in them, which was unfortunate since one of our members is a vegetarian. 

For our entrees, three of us ordered the Tofu Vegetable noodle soup (hu tieu chay) and the fourth ordered the Spicy Chicken Chow Mein (mi xao ga cay). Overall, we were all perfectly satisfied. My soup was just what I needed with a generous amount of sriracha and jalapenos added, it was delicious.

Definitely a great place to stop in on a chilly San Francisco evening and warm up.
author: Emily S.

description:
As a self-proclaimed connoisseur of salads, I must say their shaken beef salad is top notch. Juicy, peppered steak pieces, large quarters of fresh tomato, and spicy soy dipping sauce with slices of jalapeños. It's a hefty amount of beef, which merits the $10.95 price tag.

The lettuce of the salad leaves something to be desired, which is why I went 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Ross A.

description: Solid neighborhood Vietnamese option with affordable dishes and friendly service. We had a lovely family style meal for 4 with the pancake appetizer, eggplant side, clay pot catfish and grilled pork and shrimp noodles. Clay pot catfish felt the most authentic but the other dishes were quite good nonetheless. This is a great add to our regular rotation.
author: Aman H.

description:
I've been coming here for about 10 years.Not bad despite some of the
other reviewers horror stories.Maybe I'm not one for soup & noodles! I
suggest trying the chow mein,meat & seafood stir fry plates with white
rice,eggs rolls,& grilled BBQ pork (sliced & whole).The last is heavily 
marinated,so might make you burp for a day! Otherwise,good & above
average in taste.Just wish the take out portions were complete filled boxes and not 3/4 of the way filled.Take a chance on this place.
author: Buddha B.

description: It started with a craving for a vietnamese sandwich.  This assuaged it.  End of story.  Prices are somewhat on the pricey end for vietnamese food and you don't get a lot but the food was enough.
author: Jessica P.

description:
As a native to San Jose and a possessor of a Vietnamese mother, my expeditions for pho have been very hit or miss in San Francisco. Maybe I need to put all my claws out and explore the Tenderloin or trek super far to Clement. But luckily we found this 10-minute-to-walk-to spot in the Mission.

I had their pho. (I love noodles btw). And I could not complain. The noodles weren't soggy (I hate, loathe, despise, want to kill soggy noodles and/or those who produce it) and the broth was tasty. The beef was pretty tender too. It was exactly what I had been wanting. Just a pleasant bowl of pho. I think I want this again tonight, but it's only Wednesday and I'm only allowed to eat out on Fridays and Saturdays now. Wah. 

I can't say it's the best pho I've ever had. I don't know if the best pho ever actually exists. But I left pretty happy.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant.  I come here once a week for the soup. It is consistently good.... And no gristle, which is my pet peeve with pho. I would dare say I like the soup better than Slanted Door's.
author: H G.

description: Very good egg rolls, and chicken chowmein. Good quantity in cheap price... Can't beat that!
author: Darshz N.

description: My go-to place for a good banh mi. They strike just the right balance -- not too healthy, not too greasy.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Mmmmm, pho. 

It doesn't take much, pho-wise, to keep me happy. Give me a generous portion of sides and sizeable chicken pieces (done and done) and I'm happy. 

This place delivered pho-wise. I also split some spring rolls, which were good as well. Granted, I haven't ever had bad spring rolls... But still.

Service was prompt and friendly, and we were seated right away on a Thursday evening.
author: Sonia M.

description: If you get a la carte it's a ton of meat and veggies (no rice). Great for two meals. Vermicelli bowls, pho, and five spice chicken are all delicious.
author: Heather R.

description:
I LOVE this place.  I wish I lived in Mission so I could hang out here more.  

I had some fried rice thing with beef.  Who cares about the beef.  I am a fried rice fanatic and this is the best one I have had in the bay!   The beef was great too but I almost forgot about it because of the rice.

My friend got the vermacelli which he loved too.  But who cares about him...back to the rice.  Tender, just enough veg and spice.  I always add some sriracha, that's just the way it is.  Man, I am having dreams about this rice.  I have to go back soon!

Love!
author: Stacey C.

description:
So, it states loud and proud that it is a Vietnamese establishment and we had had a delicious meal at Sunflower the other night in Potrero Hill so we just ducked in here one Saturday night. It was hot and sweaty inside, quite loud, and a very chill and laid back atmosphere that was pleasantly promising for some good cheap eats. 
Upon closer inspection of the menu it seemed to be a whole lot of your standard Chinese food restaurant offerings so we went with Tofu Hot and Sour Soup and a BBQ pork & imperial roll vermicelli noodle bowl. The noodle bowl was underwhelming and went largely ignored but OMG that was some of the best hot and sour soup I've ever had!! We were literally competing for the last slurp! It would've been even tastier if it was served with real porcelain soup spoons, not flimsy plastic ones, but given the environment and price point, it was all good. 
I really appreciate the large assortment of sauces on every table. 
I would probably not seek out this place again amongst all of the other fine Vietnamese restaurants in the city.
author: Libra J.

description: I cannot imagined not living next door to this Thai restaurant. The perfect mom's cooking place where you can just do that -- eating mom's home cooked dishes. The service is homely, there's nothing extra special about the service to entice you to come back, etc, but it is quick and simple --  'what do you want to eat today, sir? ' From padhai to pho to lemongrass BBQ pork sub, this place is a gem for the Valencia/Mission residents. For a quick fix, and if you are craving thai, head here. Satisfaction guaranteed.
author: Ambrose A.

description:
This is one great place to have vermicelli noodle bowls.  My bf ordered the lemongrass beef over vermicelli and it was like grabbing a bowl from my mom's kitchen!  The meat was so tender and the flavors were right on!  I had the (usually can't go wrong dish) egg roll and BBQ chicken over vermicelli, which was seasoned well and included very fresh veggies.  The service on this particular night was slow, but with great authentic meals in our bellies, we weren't too disappointed. 

To conclude, skip the line at Sunflower and enjoy your Vietnamese food fix at Thanh Tam!  Delicious!!!
author: Lisa R.

description:
I love coming here to get my #39 Special Combination Beef noodle soup. The Combination Wonton noodle soup is awesome also. I haven't found another pho place in the Mission with a selection as good as the one at Thanh Tam II. The service is always attentive and I never wait more than 10 minutes for my food!! The prices are right and the serving sizes are proper.  Make a trip to Thanh Tam II ! 

Delivery Service is on hit too, especially for those rainy days.
author: Raymon B.

description:
BEWARE: They don't deliver until after 5pm!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

That was not clear on their website or Yelp.
author: Erika D.

description:
Super-fast delivery in the Mission!!!

I really liked this pho. The combo was great -- the rare beef was sooo tender and tasty, there was tripe but not too much, plus enough tendon and the well-done meat too. 

AND, they gave some cock sauce + hoisin sauce, bonus points.

I would've preferred some lime to the tiny bit of lemon, but the broth is tasty so I'll forgive them this time.

The cold pork & shrimp rolls were nice. The lemongrass beef was just OK -- I've had better.
author: Dina G.

description:
I was absolutely craving a Vietnamese Sandwhich last night and the closest place to get one was Thanh Tam. It is a standard Vietnamese restaurant with the offerings of pho, vermicelli, and rice plates. 

I was upset that there was a hunk of cucumber in my sandwhich, instead of a julienne cut that has been in every single place that I've eaten at... texture makes that sandwhich what it is! 

The space is a bit crammed. I went up to pay for my bill and the older woman at the counter had 6 in front of her... apparently she gestured to me which one was mine... but it took an awkward 3 minutes of me standing in front of her to actually get my bill [I had no idea what she meant... don't we usually get handed our bills?] 

The reason I gave them two stars is because nothing really stood out to me. It didn't entirely suck, but neither my experience or my food left me with an impression to come back.
author: Megan V.

description:
I can only rate the Pho. Having come from LA, I have had some good pho in my day. I thought the meat here was very average and the soup was somewhat bland. I ordered takeout (pho is usually better in person, admittedly) but they got my order totally wrong (I specifically asked for no tripe and beef balls, and they added tripe and no beef balls). As the order was wrapped in a bag and boxed, I didn't go through to check the order. 

In summary: Pho is very average. Check your order if you're ordering take out.
author: Kyle L.

description: It's a hit or miss with this place.  My usual order is the bun this nuong cha gio (rice noodles with eggrolls and bbq pork) and it hits the spot.  They are authentic vietnamese and so service is quick, but sparse.  I would recommend.
author: A B.

description: Food was good, but it took over 15 minutes to get our check.   The waiter was taking care of everyone else and ignoring us.  Would probably go back for take-out.
author: Frances F.

description: quality is going down...the pho broth, meat are not fresh anymore...ingredients pitifully small in quantities. Everything else may still be ok...but i don't really go there anymore...
author: Xiu L.

description: I wouldn't say it's the best vietnamese restaurant but I think it is in this neighborhood! If ur around and u r craving vietnamese food this is the place ;)
author: Rio S.

description:
I've walked by and passed up a meal at Thanh Tam II  a numnber of times because it was always too busy, but  the place was empty this afternoon and I was able to get a seat at the only window table.  

I was a little confused by the menu because they have a variety of Chinese dishes listed --  fried rice and chow mein, chow fun, won ton, hot & sour soup and other things that didn't sound very Vietnamese to me but I didn't  try any of them. 

Thank Tam apparently specializes in cheap $5 Vietnamese sandwiches for lunch, which a couple of guys ordered after I arrived, but I was in the mood for pho.  So, I ordered a medium bowl of steak & tripe pho (my favorite) w/the steak on the side (so it's not overcooked).  

The pho came quickly.  My immediate reaction was that it was kinda small -- even for a med sized pho - and that there wasn't much meat (steak or tripe).  Only a few slivers of tripe and 5 slices of steak for $7.95.  Came w/the side plate of basil, bean sprouts, sliced peppers and a wedge of lemon (instead of lime).  The flavor of the broth was very good and tasted as it should, but I was still hungry after finishing the bowl.

Service after the pho was delivered was indifferent.  After I was done, I had to walk back to the counter where the waitress was "busy" reading texts or emails on her phone.  I'm usually pretty good about tipping, especially at Asian restaurants, but I didn't give her a tip because of that. 

Poor service but decent food is apparently a hallmark of this restaurant. which would rate 3 stars, but the relatively high price and small serving size drop it a notch in my book. 

So, 2 stars from me because I've definitely experienced better but if you're in the mood for pho and are in the area, you should be satisfied w/the quality of the dish but, if you're hungry, order a large bowl for a buck more just to make sure you get enough to eat.
author: Martin C.

description:
Came here after watching The Nutcracker with my girls (5). 

It was definitely small inside, but the waiter was friendly. There was a decent amount of pho noodles, but rarely any meat. The price was okay, but if I paid this much for a bowl of pho in chinatown, I would've gotten more.

Overall, this place is okay, and i'll come here again if i'm hungry for vietnamese cuisine and am in the mission district, but i'm not a fan.
author: Diane L.

description: I love pho and always looking around for new Vietnamese places but still always come back here. . .
author: Colin H.

description: Excellent food and pretty cheap.  We got the salt &. Pepper pork chops, beef sandwich, and eggplant with spicy sauce/basil.  They were all excellent and we have enough left for a one of us to have a big lunch tomorrow.
author: Laura A.

description:
Well,

where do I start? I went here last night with some friends, i ordered the salt and pepper shrimp as an appetizer. The shrimps were whole, unskinned, heads on, w/o mud vain removed, deep fried in a tempura type batter almost to hide the fact they came right out of the bag they were delivered in. I decided to ask kindly for another dish, the manager, told me that what they have cooked, you have to pay for. All I wanted was a replacement dish.

She was not budging. I told her that I would not pay for it and demanded either for it to be dropped from the bill or replaced, she told me that she would call the police if i didnt pay for it.

When we made more of an issue, she started going around to other tables at the restaurant asking them if we were being irrational and yelling at us the whole time. 

What a joke of an establishment, we paid our bill and left all the while getting yelled at.

honestly, if you want crap food, and terrible service, check this place out.
author: Victoria G.

description:
I wanted to like this place, since they had an exciting vegetarian menu, and Sunflower was unexpectedly closed. 

Now I know why Sunflower seems much more popular...the Vietnamese crepe was greasy and gummy in the middle. The vegetarian spicy eggplant rice plate was more than half rice with what seemed like only a few bites of (not spicy) eggplant.  All in all, the portions were not worth the price (maybe it's better to get soup?) and the food, while we ate all of it, was not that tasty.

Also, I know this place is apparently famous for flies in the entry, and I can excuse that, but there were not one, but two, dead fruit flies floating in the crepe dipping sauce. Kinda gross that there are so many in the kitchen apparently as well.

I'll stick to Sunflower, when it isn't Tuesday.  Even though the service is probably worse, the food is better, at least for a veggie, as far as I can tell.
author: Tamara F.

description:
I walked in not expecting much, and maybe that's why I was so happy with the meal.  True, the decor is generic-asian-stripmall-restaurant, and the TV above the counter was a distraction, but the food was tasty and even on a Friday night there was no wait. 

We got the salt and papper calamari, which was spicy and tender and wonderful, grilled shrimp bun, which had tons of shrimp, fresh veggies, and a balanced flavor, and lemongrass tofu, which was also very good.  

After eating here, I'm just over Sunflower.  This was better, cheaper, and I didn't have to cower in a corner waiting for a table.  Tho next time I might opt for take out.
author: Dana S.

description:
Came here on a cold and windy Tuesday night to decompress a little bit, dine with myself, watch the Giants game close-captioned while eating a delicious bowl of hot something. 

Thanh Tam delivered all this and more. The pho was solid - light, brothy, umami, filled with meaty goodies - and decently priced. The cooks accidentally made an extra order of fried bananas and the waiter walked from table to table distributing them for free! A great SF attitude here.

I probably wouldn't seek this place out if I didn't live two blocks from here. It's not a destination restaurant, just a good option in the neighborhood.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Came here with Corey V last week, and all I could think was: why haven't I eaten here before?? I'm a pho lover who lives about one block from this restaurant.  It just makes no sense.  I think I tried Sunflower nearby, and ended up sticking with that one. Bad choice!

The pho here was pretty darned good. TTII also has egg noodle dishes when you're having a craving for more Hong Kong-style noodle soups.

However, the smell of cleaning solution did dampen my enjoyment of the meal.
author: Sid D.

description:
Wandering over here during an off period (between lunch and dinner) and this place looked pretty crowded, which to me is a good sign. Their pan-fried Crispy style noodles House Special was more Chinese than Vietnamese but was quite good with fresh quality ingredients.

Their "Appetizer" Vietnamese Pancake was almost $9.00 but was a huge folded omelet and again freshly prepared with beansprouts and cilantro, mint, green leafy lettuce, and shrimp with of course the terrific fish sauce on the side. Actually, if the fish sauce weren't there, the pancake would have been under-seasoned. My wife rated that pancake about 2.5 but I liked it more and guess who wrote this up :)?

The service was quick if perfunctory and the value was pretty good. 

I would certainly go again if in this neighborhood.
author: Glenn H.

description: I've tasted better Vietnamese dishes than the ones offered here.  But the price is good.  Parking is not so good for those not familiar with the Mission area.  There's definitely room to improve on the food - so maybe I wil come back after and make another review.
author: Nixon L.

description:
It's not great, it's not bad.  Just kind of average.  A little confusing regarding the seating policy, but on the plus side, the food was out quickly.  

The pho was okay, very little meat in the medium size portion--only 3 or 4 slices. Also, my friend and I had our bowls mixed up, but we weren't entirely certain until it was a little too late.  She needs the calories more than I do, anyway!

Not sure if I'll be back, but not against it, either.
author: Aim B.

description:
I really like this place.  The five spice chicken is the best dish I've had there.  The chicken is super tender and grilled to perfection.  They don't skimp on the chicken portions, but it's not too much either.  

They recently started selling Vietnamese sandwiches for $5.  They put plenty of grilled chicken in there.

I've had their bun with beef and imperial rolls.  Imperial rolls are great.  I love their marinade.  

Reasonable prices, really good Vietnamese food.  I really recommend this place.
author: Katie L.

description:
Minus two stars. 

Here's how the first got dropped: 

I can say "no peanuts" in Vietnamese. So I did, in addition to English. And I still got peanuts on my vermicelli. Ugh. It's not just a preference; if I eat peanuts I WILL DIE. I've learned my lesson. I just stopped ordering anything that requires me to make this request. This means my food options here have been cut by about a quarter. Too bad. The vermicelli with imperial roll and shrimp is sooooooo good.

Minus the other star for this....

When I order pho, I expect:
* broth
* meat
* noodles
* veggies and sauces

This time, I got:
* broth

When I called to ask nicely for the rest of my food, I got:
* a hard time
* harassed about how I was trying to get free food.

Eventually the lady on the phone relented and the driver returned with the rest of my friend's pho. He got there about 2 minutes later, which suggests to me that he just forgot the rest in his car. He was nice and apologetic about it, unlike his co-worker the Pho Harpy.

Lessons learned:
* don't eat here if you have food restrictions
* beware the delivery; it's fast, but make sure the driver sticks around while you inspect the order.

I also discovered recently that Jasmine Garden delivers. They're at least as tasty, know how to leave the peanuts off, and do more accurate deliveries.

Original review:

The only place I know of that will deliver me pho.  I alternate between the special combination pho and the rice vermicelli with grilled shrimp and egg roll.  Christ, that's good.  They tell me they use gluten-free rice paper for the egg rolls, which I will presume to be true because my tummy doesn't hurt after eating here.  We've had some miscommunication in the past about my need for no peanuts on my food, but they have served me a new bowl of food minus the peanuts when they've brought me a death bowl by accident.

And yeah, the service here isn't awesome, but I haven't had a problem with it.  They've always refilled my water glass and brought me the check without grumbling.  Plus, if they are willing to bring me de-peanutted food, they can't be all bad.

Oh, did I mention they will DELIVER PHO????  Which is awesome since I am sitting at home sick right now and only pho can fix me.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description:
These guys know their stuff. They have an extensive menu - all of your Vietnamese favorites are here, plus some Chinese ones.

My girlfriend had the vegetable tofu soup, which probably isn't actually vegetarian since it definitely tastes of chicken broth, but it was delicious nevertheless. I had the grilled pork and egg roll noodle bowl and it was awesome. The egg roll was especially crispy and filled with goodness. Vietnamese places usually pad these noodle bowls with lettuce at the bottom, and while Thanh Tam II doesn't escape this fate, they don't fill it to the brim with the stuff either. Oh, and their egg soda ain't half bad.

I'm taking one star off for the decor, which is kind of dark and gloomy. Purple walls and overhanging mood lights. Glad we got a seat by the window because we might have been too depressed to eat our food otherwise.
author: Jeffrey F.

description: Review for Pho- It's great pho, it's fast and tastes yummy. The fried rolls and fresh rolls are also very tastey. I work near here and would come in anytime I'm craving pho.
author: Chayne J.

description:
Dropped in here on a whim and had Bún ch and a good bowl of Pho...both were extremely filling and...surprisingly good!! For some reason I didn't think this little place could deliver, but it did and then some!

Bottomline, order either one or the other, or you will explode!
author: Paolo D.

description:
Tranh Tam II is a good place to come in two circumstances.  

1.  Your name is Tranh Tam I, the prince of Persia, or at any rate, of some actually Asian country, and you wish to eat at a place named after your family. 

2.  If you want cheap, fast Vietnamese food and don't really want to wait for Sunflower across the street.  The food isn't amazing, but then, it's cheap and fast, and their Imperial Rolls are better than average.  Who's complaining?  Not I!  

3 Imperial (roll) Stars.
author: Leon K.

description: Last time I was here it was pretty good, but my last experience was a grease factory & bland for the Combination Chow Ho Fun :(
author: S. R.

description:
i don't know what they did but their veggie and tofu rice plate that i had become obsessed with while attending school down the street has morphed and is now less flavorful.

this makes me sad.

also, i'm a little over the service issue.  whenever the yelling lady is taking orders and delivering dishes i'm a bit frightened.  she's not only a yeller she's a scowler and will make you wait an eternity for the check.

i'm heading back to sunflower on the regular now.  the dudes at the valencia street side of sunflower rock it with a smile no matter how busy the joint is and they at least have one veggie friendly pho.
author: Jen I.

description:
* 3.5 stars *

I like the food here better than the last place I reviewed up the street.

Large portions, friendly service, all around yum.

The shrimps here are pretty zesty.

I dunno, something about appeals to me (not enough to make me jump in joy but still decent eats).

Has a cool atmosphere, too.

I recommend 'em.
author: Kai S.

description: I love this place. I cannot stand Sunflower across the street. This place's Pho is consistent and always delicious. VERY good prices and always fresh food. I love this place!
author: William M.

description: Best banh mi I've ever had! 5 for the food (very substantial portions). Service was a little slow, so 4 overall. I'll definitely be back.
author: Jessica M.

description: there's a reason some places survive when bubbles hit a neighborhood...good food!  had the bo luc lac (shaken beef) and it was really good. quick, tasty, not too expensive. friendly staff; looks mom and pop.  def a go-to type place for mission.  2 other vietnamese in the hood worth visiting, but can't go wrong here.
author: Roy N.

description: OK, it's kind of weird to review a place from which you've only had one dish, and always get take out  But the Tofu Banh Mi is $5 and SO FREAKING GOOD.  Super fresh, full of amazing pickled vegetables, and with a serious kick.  (If you don't like spicy, have 'em leave off the jalapenos.) I guess if you eat at Thanh Tam, 1) have a thick skin (the service sounds brusque) and 2) don't order the Pho.  That is all.
author: Joe B.

description:
Uhhh-mazing.

Once you get over the queasiness that fluorescent-green lighting seems to induce, you will LOVE this cheap and yummy delight. In fact, I have been twice in one week.

Vietnamese spring rolls--a standard, and the peanut sauce tops it beautifully. 

Pho--pretty standard as well, a perfect dish if you're looking to keep it light--i.e. holding back on sweet and sticky sauces.

The chow mein and the garlic eggplant dishes use the afore-mentioned sauces with great gusto, and I wasn't disappointed. I love the crispy veggie chow mein and the (wet?) shrimp chow mein.

Final LOVE: Asparagus and Crab soup. SLURP! An eggy delight, although it skimped a little on the crab.

Finally: Extremely disappointed by the beef and bok choy. The beef was the pinnacle of tenderized grossness. But I was so into the other dishes that I still think this place deserves 5 stars in relation to price, quantity and taste ratios.

The service was rapid-fire both times I went and the ladies in the back were super-sweet about making sure we had ordered everything we needed before they closed the kitchen.
author: Liane G.

description: I like this place. It's cheap and small and fast. Nothing fancy. Just good vietnamese food. I go here whenever Sunflower has that weird B.O. smell that sometimes plagues it.
author: Charles B.

description:
Bad. Just bad. Hot and Spicy beef noodle soup was neither hot&spicy nor had much beef in it.
Not satisfied, I ordered the pancake which was just plain disgusting.
Stay away.
author: Pramod S.

description:
Affordable, fast dinner spot

FOOD:
Rice plate with five-spice chicken
~$7
Chicken was flavorful and not dry. I couldn't tell what made this dish particularly Vietnamese. It came with a side salad, which was the normal lettuce with carrots, cucumber, etc. and a small dish with a sweet and sour dipping sauce. The plate had a lot of rice, which I couldn't finish. Overall, good value for the quality and quantity of food you get.

AMBIANCE: Small narrow restaurant. Pretty quiet. No fancy decor. The single bathroom was only so-so clean.

SERVICE: Fine.

VISIT DETAILS:  Late-ish dinner
author: C L.

description:
Discussion of quality of the food is made obsolete by a negative encounter I had with their management.  

I tried them for a take away order, two dishes.    (can one order chicken with some reprieve from the wheel of life?)

The container for one of the dishes, my dish, was broken at the bottom.  Specifically, equal damage to a clean knife slice across the length of the base of the food container.  This resulted in mess and embarrassment.  

I returned to the restaurant with the damaged food container, asking if the manager would give me an apology.  The manager gave an evasive sideways apology.  I asked for a beer that I would drink in restaurant.  The manager was evasive, with garbled unintelligible language while jerkily making small movements, along with his staff who backed him, similarly to the nervous scanning movements of desert gerbils who rise on haunches nervously scanning horizons for predators.  The manner was unfriendly.  My tone  conveyed accusation, though was also expository. 

After a 20 second delay, instead of bringing me a beer, the owner asked me how he could know that I didn't drop the container, which hypothesized I was in error for complaining about damaged containers (indeed the container looked like it had been sabotaged).  I asked the manager why I would complain about a damaged container if I had dropped it myself, and if he was calling me a liar.  There was no beer served.  Then the dinner I had brought over in transferred container was dropped by my clumsiness onto the floor.   I thought I would leave the restaurant without the beer I wanted;  I ended up leaving without my dinner as well.  There was no offer to replace my spilled food.


Perhaps I would not be inflamed if I had not had civil rights violated by san francisco police in recent history, whose violence considering context and evidence that was available to them could only be judged as paradigmatic.  There is a police station across the street from this viet namese restaurant.   Incidentally, I am looking for a lawyer to assist me in organizing some form of retaliatory legal action against members of the police department, the sheriff's department, and some legal officers.  

I suppose when forthright communications fail to willful evasions and malpractice of state-empowered groups it's yelp or bruce wayne.
author: Nicholas B.

description: the good news is: extensive menu, delicious spring rolls and chicken noodle soup.  the bad news is:  NOTHING without MSG.  Which relegated one member of our party to watching, sighing, and wiping the occassional tear from his eye as we ate.  (Sure, we could have gone to another place, but we had already ordered before we remembered to enquire AND hell, the kids were hungry.)  Dang.  Also:  service was pretty good.
author: Deidre S.

description:
For those who insist on going to Sunflower Cafe, they are doing themselves a GREAT disservice by not going to Thanh Tam II. Thanh Tam's pho broth is richer and they offer more ingredients to throw in the mix. The fact that they can put put tripe in their pho already puts them at an advantage over Sunflower. The ingredients are fresher and their menu selection is much broader. Next time, I will definitely try their rice plates (pork chop and egg. yum!) and their banh mi.

Not only that, it's much cleaner and the service is better. You can actually touch the menus without feeling like you have to wear gloves.

PLEASE do yourself a favor and just walk across the street to Than Tam.
author: Faustomatic d.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco.  The way I know if it is real authentic Vietnamese is by ordering the imperial rolls.  Theirs definitely passed the test: big, tasty, spiced right and more importantly rolled in rice paper.  I also enjoy the noodle dishes (pork and shrimp are my favorite) and my girlfriend loves the crepe.  If you go there for lunch try the Vietnamese sandwich.  This place is unpretentious, delicious and affordable.  Please keep it this way...
author: Monkey B.

description:
Mmmm... Vegetarian Spring Rolls.
Fast and Free Delivery over $15

Nuff Said
author: Sara G.

description: The folks here are really nice. They totally understood when we changed our order to a to go one because my BF couldn't find parking. I ordered the grilled chicken and egg roll over rice and my BF got chicken fried rice. Both were served piping hot and they tasted decent. It wasn't too busy either which was a bonus because we had to be somewhere later. Their menu has a good selection of dishes so there's something for everyone, especially if you're not a big pho fan. The prices were pretty reasonable, we spent just under twenty bucks including a tip for two items. Not bad for a recommendation of one of my BF's friends.
author: Amy J.

description: Best pho in the city. I stumbled across Thanh Tam one night by accident and after I had their pho I was hooked. I told the owner one day that their pho broth was the best I'd ever had and she told me it was because they cook their broth for 10 hours. The broth is so good that you need not add siracha or hoysin to it at all, just a couple chili slices and basil leaves and you are set. Their chicken and seafood soups are really good as well, although not as excellent as the pho. Other great dishes are the salt and pepper prawns or salt and pepper pork chops, and grilled chicken and fried eggs over rice (be sure to order the eggs cooked only on one side and break the yolks all over the chicken and rice - outstanding). I used to go to sunflower across the street, but after discovering Thanh Tam I wouldn't go into sunflower to ask for parking meter change.
author: Benny A.

description: Very good shrimp and pork rolls, very good pho, very good rice vermicelli dishes!
author: CatsPjs Z.

description: lovely neighborhood place. affordable and quick and tasty!
author: Danielle J.

description: Hole-in-the wall and walking by you will mistake it for another Valencia dive bar, especially right next to the well-lit Urbun Burger join next door.  Have no fear, step inside and order yourself a plate of shaking beef salad or bun thit nuong because they're pretty good! They marinate the meat it just right and the fish sauce is superb (it's what makes bun thit nuong for me and my dad).  The other dishes on the encyclopedic menu are ok, and the soups are nothing to write home about, so try these two dishes first! :)  I will have to come back to try their banh xeo :)
author: Ben T.

description:
The vegetarian spring rolls with peanut sauce are to die for.  My support group orders take-out from here a lot and we always order the vegetarian spring rolls...they are SO damn good.  They're big, filling, and extremely tasty.  Most def. a culinary treat!

The only thing is, the place needs some cleain'.  The walls are pretty dirty.  Not pleasant if you go in for a meal and you're sitting next to a wall of gunk.  Gross.
author: Jenna V.

description:
I have officially lifted my embargo on Vietnam.  I vowed to vehemently abhor all things Vietnamese, including restaurants, after a college roommate experience gone bad.  Khanh was her name, and deception was her game.  She befriended my mom and would call her when I came home too late or when I spiked my breakfast lemonade with Apple Pucker before finals.  Said ratting earned her the nickname Khanhvict, which I called her behind her back, like a mature 18 year old.

Somehow, after 8 years of boycotting an entire country, I have decided to make peace with Vietnam - and all because of Thanh Tam II and $14 worth of tasty food.  How my life has been worth living these past few years, I am unsure.  Grilled pork noodle & chicken with mixed vegetables?!  Heck yes!  For introducing me, and evidently half of the Yelp staff, I think a certain yelper deserves an extra fortune cookie. 

Free delivery on orders over $20.  But it's hard to order $20 worth of food here.  Give it a shot - You'll need to order at least 3 dishes, and after you finish, considering the portion sizes, you'll be the size of Vietnam.

They also serve Chinese food.  Which both confuses and intrigues me.
author: Janney B.

description:
Hello, lemongrass tofu. Pleased to meet you. Look forward to seeing you again. And again. And again. 

Hey, who was your friend? Vegetarian Spring Rolls? Nice. Be sure to bring him around, too. That package (of fresh vegetables and mild tofu) was stuffed! and oozing! (with peanut sauce that isn't anything special, but happens to be PEANUT SAUCE, which always deserves the gesture of caps lock). 

Quick, easy, relatively clean, tasty... the qualities I look for in Casual Encounters posts and my lunch spots. Perhaps someday I could kill two birds with one Thanh Tham stone. 'Til then, I'll satisfy my need for girth with rice paper-wrapped bites.
author: haley d.

description:
Ya wanna know what's wrong with a dinner for $14.37? 

Absolutely nothing. Yep, thanks to some recent splurgin' in the ol' wallet department, I have found my social outings fallin' on some hard times. As a result, cutting back is a necessity at the moment, but never fear because dining on the cheap is yet another one of my favorite past times! :)

And so, my platonic hubby suggested Thanh Tam II and since he wears the hypothetical pants in our hypothetical marriage, I played the part of the good woman and followed him there...4 steps behind. What did we order? The chicken fried rice and the chicken with mixed vegetables. Yum. We took our orders back to his house, cracked open a bottle of vino and dined in excellence. 

Was it the best Vietnamese exploration for my palate I've ever had? Naaah, but for under $15.00 for 2 people to eat and be full, sign me up! :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
A majority of my teenage years was spent dishwashing in my mom's restaurant. It is my "whoa is me" Abe Lincoln story. I'd take a bus an hour and a half each way to make minimum wage cleaning other people's disgusting glop in a hot box of foul smelling trash. If you ask my parents, this experience was supposed to teach me the importance of hard work, sacrifice, yada yada yada. Fuck No. It taught me RESTAURANT WORK IS FOR SUCKERS.

So since I've been on the other side, I usually cut a restaurant a lot of slack when it comes to "service". I've never returned a wrong order, asked for more water, or generally complained about my food. Until my experience at Thanh Tam II, that is. Everything about my experience was AWFUL. The dining room is dirty, the service was rude and took forever, the food barely passable.  

I've never been to Thanh Tam I on mission street, but if it's anything like Thanh Tam II, don't expect to see a Thanh Tam III anytime soon. I'd rather sit through another viewing of "Legally Blonde II: Red, White and Blonde" than eat here again.

On a positive note, the dishwashing was superb. 1 star.
author: John T.

description:
I like this place better than sunflower!

why?

1.Better customer service (not rude)
2. They Deliver
3, Food presentation yummy 
4. Not crowded (has better seating room)
5. You will not smell like the food when you leave (not smokey)
author: Aemar E.

description:
I'll admit it - I'm a bit of a pho snob.  (Faux snob?)  Having spent years in the 408 and hanging out with Vietnamese friends, I've gained quite an appreciation for this ubiquitous Vietnamese treat, and I've had a handful of favorite spots in the South Bay and Peninsula.  After moving to the city, I've been searching for a bowl of noodles, beef broth, and meat that'll really tickle my fancy.

The search continues...

Thanh Tam's food is unbelievably average. It's the Jay Leno of Vietnamese restaurants: Acceptable enough to tolerate on occasion, but completely lacking any sort of flair. A meal that you'll put down, but not hear anyone at the table saying, "Mmm, you've gotta try this." Admittedly, the imperial egg rolls here are mighty tasty, but when aren't they?

I would've awarded two stars for overall mediocrity + the imperial egg rolls... But a day after eating here, I had a little group email with the friends who had accompanied me. 

Me: "Hey guys - anyone else have a funky stomach last night or today?"

Friend 1: "Yeah, I did."

Friend 2: "Me, too. It started hitting me on the drive home last night!"

So after a series of inquisitive emails and hard hitting questions and finding common threads, we deduced that our respective cases of the runs were not caused by the beer at Zeitgeist. Nor were they caused by the beer at Kilowatt. Hmmm, what could it be?  God damn Thanh Tam!
author: Omid T.

description:
They make their egg rolls with traditional rice paper - not lumpia wrappers.   That's enough for 4 stars for me.  I sometimes come here to get 1 order of egg rolls - that's it.  

Other tips:  Stick with the Vietnamese rice plates and bun (cold noodle dishes).  They are really good here, particularly the grilled pork dishes.  Pass on the Chinese food - it's average at best.  

**Also, this is not a pho house.  Rule of thumb for pho is to ONLY get it at a place that specializes in it.   Those who come here and order pho, well....don't.  That's just not their specialty - you'll be disappointed.
author: Chi L.

description: This is an awesome Vietnamese restaurant.  I would definitely go back.  I liked the spicy eggplant.  The Ho Chow Fun.
author: Joel G.

description:
Small and friendly family owned spot. Love the pho, imperial rolls and five spiced chicken.

I'm not a fan of the potstickers which are deep fried instead of pan fried.
author: Evan W.

description: Ate lunch a couple of times over here too. Seems like they were putting less and less flank and meat on their pho that I ordered although the menu mentioned that it had these ingredients. I can't believe I kept on coming back here even after I started noticing this. I guess it must be the starbucked-type lighting that had my brainwashed for awhile.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
Get the Sugar Cane Shrimp appetizer and thank me later, son!

Basically it's a do-it-yourself spring-roll with rice-noodle-paper you even moisten in a warm-water bowl yourself.

Bombest shit ever. 

#12 on the menuuuuuuuuu!
author: B S.

description:
Pho broth should NOT be brown, sweet and milky, but that's how Thanh Tam served it. It's almost as if the secret ingredient were molasses! Don't taunt me with experimental crap in my pho! A good pho broth, as we all know, should be clear (or nearly clear), with an aromatic hint of ginger and anise. In this bowl, I could sense neither. Then the bill taunted me a second time! Too expensive for 1 bowl of pho-king pho.

I ordered pho with raw beef on the side (pho bo tai). The beef was very high quality, which unfortunately I couldn't say for the broth. The Vietnamese coffee I ordered came out already prepared. GOD! I hate that. I wanted the damned Vietnamese filter at my table, so I could watch the coffee percolate as I ate my pho. But I guess this is my fault, since I don't seem to know how to order what I want.  

And no, I didn't yell "Pho Q!" at the waitress, don't even start with the bad Pho jokes. But I do admit I am a little pho-king irritated. ;)
author: Daniel C.

description:
Review strictly for the soup and fresh spring rolls.

I love soup, and I love a good BBQ pork fun noodle soup. It was excellent broth, excellent thick noodles, good vegetables and wonderful broth. And it was steaming hot. SCORE. The fresh spring rolls were awesome,  thickly filled and very fresh., I will be back.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Yes, their menus are a little creepy with a woman staring vapidly at you from the front cover, but it just adds to the charm, right? 

Pho is the the go-to hangover cure, naturally, and this place is one of the best for it. Cheap for a giant bowl of pho and all the fixins, and a myriad of sauces for those in my life that prefer their pho tasting like Roosters and Plums. I can never finish a bowl, and believe me I try. For pho I'd definitely head here over Sunflower. Its a working man's food, and by work I mean drinking and by man I mean liver. This hits the spot every time.

Aside from this, service is good, and the water, for some reason, is extra satisfyingly cold and delicious. Its never crowded, good for me, maybe not so good for Thanh Tam but never completely empty either.
author: sholeh m.

description:
Oh, how I wish there were decent Vietnamese in the Mission.  

Sometimes I just crave it, but can't drag myself to the Richmond or Sunset to get the real deal. Like yesterday. So again, I end up at Thanh Tam II, someplace I considered reliable, if not particularly spectacular, to address my pho needs.  

Oy vey. Maybe it's gone downhill, or maybe my eyes weren't open wide enough before. I've never expected fancy, but I do want a basic level of sanitation. 

First bad sign: when we sat down, my friend said, "Do you smell that? it's...the rags they used to wipe the table." Indeed, there was a mix of inglorious stink wafting through --I'm not sure where it was from.  

Next: I had been sipping my tea and chatting when I noticed a pink smear on my teacup. Just lipstick, I thought. Wait, I'm not wearing any lipstick... So that's... someone else's.   I almost threw up.  

We received a clean cup with no acknowledgment or apology. Now, I'm not expecting a lot from a hole-in-the-wall, not thinking there will be great service or even someone to explain anything on the menu (and there certainly wasn't).  But I do expect NOT to have someone else's rancid lipstick in my mouth!!!

Oh, and the chicken pho broth tasted like soap.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
We ordered shaken beef, fried prawns, imperial rolls, catfish and bok choy and grilled pork chops with fried eggs over rice. Everything was good and well-cooked, but some of the items were not what i expected. I'm used to shaken beef served in a pepper-y sauce with a side of pepper and lime wedges. For the fried prawns, I was expecting the type that is usually served with garlic noodles, instead, the prawns were more like large, crispy fried shrimp you could get a seafood restaurant.

It was all solid though, and despite not getting exactly what I was expecting, I would still eat there again, especially considering that they deliver.

UPDATE: I've been back several times now, and, based on other yelpers, ordered the lemongrass tofu and the scrambled shrimp and egg (a la carte). The tofu dish was light and flavorful, with crazy-huge portions. The scrambled eggs and shrimp? SCRUMPTIOUS. These 2 dishes alone are unique enough and yummy enough that I would up the rating to 3.5 stars.

Seems like with any restaurant, if you know what to order, you'll come away happy.
author: Sabine S.

description:
Although I still give it 3 stars, it's actually lower than my original 3 star rating if that makes any sense.

I got a rare beef and beef ball pho here the other night. $8.20 for the stinjiest amount of noodles and meat EVER. I don't recall getting such a small portion the last time I came here. Maybe I was expecting more because I was super hungry and craving pho. Anyway, the beef ball was literally ONE BEEF BALL. CUT IN HALF to make it look like you got two. About 4-5 small slices of rare beef, and a handful of noodles.

SUPER LAME. I'm really disappointed. Now I don't know where I'll get my pho in the Mission that's not far away from my place. =(
author: Angela H.

description:
Came here last night and we ordered the BBQ Chicken plate over rice and the BBQ Chicken and Imperial Roll with Vermicelli noodles. The dishes were yummy but the BBQ chicken was a little on the salty side.

We had to get at least 2 refills on iced water to wash the saltiness down...that's why I'm taking away one star.

Place was tiny, service was ok, food was good but a little on the expensive side for Vietnamese food. I could find other Vietnamese restaurants that are better and cheaper elsewhere.

Oh...and they deliver....I guess that would be a bonus but the minimum order for delivery is $20.
author: V M.

description:
I have only ever eaten the pho at this little place, and so maybe I'm not the best authority on their overall performance... but I maintain that this is some of the tastiest pho in the Mission.  There's always a table, it's very fast, it's exactly what you'd expect to pay, and it's good.  That, when it comes to a place servicable to my craving for pho, is good enough for me.

Should you kill yourself to eat here?  Heavens no.  If you're in the neighborhood on a budget and need a bowl of the good stuff, this will definitely do the trick better than Sunflower ever could.

And, you can have a beer.
author: Laura F.

description: A cozy, perfectly fine little Vietnamese place to chat with a friend, or read. You can be in/out in 20 minutes start to finish, so don't plan on it being an "outing" in and of itself unless you can't stand your dining partner.
author: Amy Z.

description:
If you're into service and ambience, don't bother...

Food here is awesome, though.  Cheapest decent lunch on the block. What El Toro and some of the other "cheaper" places around here charge is asinine...

Sunflower opens at noon. WTF???
author: Nathan W.

description:
I left San Francisco last year, and Thanh Tam II was one of the first things I missed about the city (along with Taqueria La Cumbre, fernet, and good Manhattans).  

For a few years, this place was a twice-weekly ritual for me.  Some combination of chicken salad, spicy curry chicken, lemongrass chicken, BBQ beef, and/or springrolls.  Always amazing food, and really cheap.  

To be fair, I got into a rut with my favorites, and I haven't tried even 20% of the menu items.  I ordered soup a few times, and it was just okay--nowhere near as good as, say, Tu Lan.  But I didn't really care... damn, I miss that lemongrass chicken.

And in the interest of full disclosure, I should also admit that the service wasn't always fabulous here--though there was a young male waiter who was great... and I should be shot for not remembering his name.  But you probably wouldn't wander into a cheap Vietnamese restaurant expecting four-star service, would you?

But yeah... crazy good food.  I'm praying that they open Thanh Tam III in my new neighborhood in DC.
author: Charles B.

description:
The vegetable noodle soup here is better here than the one at Sunflower.  

Differences:

- Tofu isn't fried
- Noodles taste fresher
- Vegetables are bigger and fresher
- The soup is better

Also, if you are a advocate for eating fried eggs on top of some kind of meat and rice.  You can order two fried eggs for any of their rice and meat combos.  It's the BOMB!!

Service can be a little slow because there is typically just one person on the floor hosting, waiting, and busing so I would cut him some slack.
author: Justin C.

description:
It seemed like everyone in San Francisco was getting sick - my friends, my co-workers, my fellow Muni riders. By the middle of February I was surprised and a little elated that I managed to make it through unscathed. That started to change Tuesday, and by 4:45am this morning I was hacking and coughing while calling work to leave a voice mail letting my boss know I wasn't going to make it in. I finally succumned to the flu of 2008.

Which meant pho was on the agenda for tonight. I wasn't going far from home, which made Thanh Tam the perfect choice.

Overall, not bad. It was crowded, but they whipped up my takeout order in less than 10min. Service was great, the guy immediately suggested the shredded chicken soup when I mentioned I was sick. Why that is listed under seafood noodle soup on the menu I have no idea. I wish there was more chicken, but it didn't seem oiled up, which was nice.

Nothing outstanding, but above average. Though if I wake up tomorrow back to normal, I'll revise with a fifth star. Wishful thinking....
author: Jason B.

description:
No wait on a Friday night. 
2 drinks + apps (veggie crepe, yum!) + 2 HUGE entrees = $20.
Lots of fresh veggies .
Stir-fried (as opposed to deep-fried) tofu & chicken.

I loved the spicy chicken lemongrass bun dish. Pair it with a Saigon beer and you have yourself a meal!
author: Anika K.

description: I will walk many blocks just for a thai iced tea from here.   Very refreshing!  Not too sweet, not too flat- juuuust right.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
We ordered dinner to be delivered and I must say I am impressed. Our food arrived in a timely fashion, the portions are large (I had enough to reheat and eat the next day!), the flavor was great, and the prices are perfect. 

I want to give them five stars, but I am going to reevaluate after I eat at the restaurant and get the full effect of Thanh Tam II!

As a dedicated vegetarian with vegan tendencies, I am more than satisfied with the tofu lemongrass noodles and the fried veggie spring rolls.

UPDATE: November 20, 2008
We went to Thanh Tam II before we left for our trip to NY. Spring rolls and a Thai iced tea and I was so full! I took the rest of my rolls, rice, and some noodles with me to the airport and ate them as a pre-flight snack. Slept soundly the whole way there, woke up refreshed and ready to go!

Not only is their food delicious, the restaurant cozy, and the service prompt - they were playing football on the TV. Everything was just perfect.
author: Rikki W.

description:
I really enjoyed my first experience here.

We started off with the deep fried pork spring rolls, delicious!  Crispy and well done.  Reminded me of the fried rolls at the Slanted Door.

Our main dish was 2 orders of the Beef Pho, thankfully I had the best company ever to show me how to season and eat it correctly.  It was delicious, the broth was so flavorful!  And ofcourse we enjoyed our meal with a Vietnamese beer, 33 Export Lagar (fantastic btw). 

Small, cozy place.  Nothing to rave about inside or outside appearance wise.  But those are usually the best places to eat anyhow.
author: Inga B.

description:
It's no Saigon Saigon, but neither are they:  they're gone, and the space is being ripped apart to be made into something new.  They weren't spectacular, but they were pretty damn good for the price.

The food at Thanh Tam was all right.  Rice bowl.  Meat.  You know.

It was okay.  It's no Saigon Saigon.....they're gone.

I miss that crazy paint job.
author: Randy F.

description: Lemongrass tofu over vermicelli is my fav food in the city. It's always good. I go here all the time and I'm not tired of it yet. Sometimes I get the spicy version instead, and it's pretty spicy but I manage to eat it! Salt and pepper tofu is a good appetizer too. Fried bananas are good for desert. The service is very friendly, they remember me and my regular order. I like the atmosphere here too.
author: Amanda L.

description:
My prefered Vietnamese restaurant over Sunflower which is close by. The family who run it are really sweet, the place is clean (my big complaint about Sunflower), the portions are large, well made, fresh and quiet. I don't know why this place isn't more crowded - I've been on weekends and during the week and I can always get  a table.

Great value for all the meals, I can't say more about this little spot.
author: Spoon G.

description:
Food was all right but when checking my credit card statement they charged us more tip than we put. It wasn't much but the intention is what counts. Definitely not going back to this place.
Romy
author: Roman O.

description: This place is consistently Delicious. If you're in the Mission and looking for some cheap, tasty Vietnamese, this is your place.
author: Mere H.

description:
Awkward date.  Great food.  Pretty cheap, which is good, since we went dutch.

Check it out.
author: Jill K.

description: I have frequented this place on many occasions, not necessarily because the food is great, or the ambiance is great, but simply because it's one of the only places in the inner mission (Sunflower being the other)  to get a bowl of pho soup. It's not the best bowl of pho I've had but It does the trick for when it's much needed. The food menu always reminds me of a mail-order bride catalog.  There are two things that are always consistent about this place, service is always quick and the fortune cookies are always stale.
author: Glenda D.

description: I finally got around to trying this place just a couple weeks before moving out of the Mission, and I wish I'd tried it earlier. As it was, I went three times in about ten days. I love the beef and egg roll vermicelli noodles, served over a delicious salad with a nice amount of cilantro. My girlfriend loved the tofu noodle soup (especially because the tofu was not fried), and we both liked the potstickers (the sauce for which goes great with everything). I also stopped in for lunch one day and had a delectable Vietnamese pork sandwich for $5. All that in a nice, quiet atmosphere. I never had it so good at Sunflower.
author: Marco L.

description:
The combination beef pho was excellent, and the service friendly and quick.  Can't really complain about the prices either.  I was the only one in the restaurant for a late lunch, and the waiter left me alone by the window for most of my meal.  That was perhaps the best bit, as I got to watch Valencia traffic for a half hour or so.

The subtle decorations and accessories--lamps, mirrors, etc.--aren't much to write about, although they are clearly from Ikea.  (How often does one need to visit a store or its website to recognize its merchandise?  I promise I'm not in Ikea all that often!)
author: Christina C.

description: Quality beef + rice dish. The cashier lady actually smiles.
author: Inigo M.

description: I was truly surprised by some of the "not so good" reviews for Thanh Tam II. I love this place. The vermicelli bowl with shrimp and egg roll is delicious. The pho is great. The spring rolls are very fresh. This place is rarely crowded and there is never a wait. If you are torn between Sunflower and this place, give Thanh Tam II a try. I doubt you will be disappointed.
author: Ryan S.

description:
been here a few times. i liked the Bun dishes better than the Pho i had. the Pho was OK, but not exceptional. the Bun was above average with perfectly grilled pork and an excellent Imperial Roll. decent amount of fixens below the noodles. i've had that the last couple times i've been here and it was consistently very good.

interesting Discovery Channel shows on TV too! ;-)

definitely better than Sunflower down the block. Sunflower's Pho Ga was bland broth with tough meat and well below average.
author: Andrew C.

description: You don't go here for amazing service or ambiance..you go here for the amazing Pho and cold rolls. I've been going around town to try to beat this place. Personally hands down the best Vietnamese food all around. It's totally resonably priced and you can always get a seat! My fave!! YAy!
author: Deandra B.

description: In a city FULL of great Vietnamese restaurants- this is the only one I've found that actually DELIVERS. And I mean that literally. I must have called about 10 places (that list themselves as delivery ) before I got to Thanh Tam II.  6 let the phone ring forever, 2 wouldn't make the 3 mile pilgrimage to my house, one number was disconnected, one was closed for Valentine's Eve. Really. But this glorious little gem came through!
