I ordered Rare steak Pho' , a vermicelli bbq beef plate and imperial rolls- everything was fresh and delicious and came in about 20 mins. sooo happy!
author: Kitty K.

description:
Do not go for the decor.

Do not go for the service.

But please, oh please go for the food. This hole in the wall would never attract you, with its garish neon sign and nondescript interior. And the plastic ugly menu might even scare you off once you were inside. But once your food comes (and at lightening speed!) You will change your mind.

I don't know why I haven't reviewed this place, I've been coming her for Pho for years. I am also a huge fan of any of the lemongrass noodles (Spicy Chicken lemongrass?? YUM).

Also, it is ridiculously cheap. It's never crowded. And you might not be charmed by the wait staff, but you will certainly feel satisfied.
author: Patrice S.

description:
This review, my very first, is for Felix.  He's Kristi's old roomie who had the privilege of hearing me go on and on about food all afternoon, Vietnamese food to be specific.  Felix's parents are both ethnic Chinese peeps who lived in Vietnam for a while.  Felix, like me, was lucky enough to grow up eating Vietnamese food.  

Today has been very cold and the beers I had this afternoon have worn off leaving me colder than cold and in the mood for some noodle soup.  I have to agree with most of the posts about Thanh Tam II - the food is by far sub-par and the service is not great - however, I live in the Mission and this is one of my default places for inexpensive Vietnamese food.  

They can be a little heavy handed on the msg (mostly in noodle soups) but for the most part the experience is fulfilling.  Today's Mi Won Ton Hai San - egg noodle soup with wontons and seafood - hit the spot.  The msg was not overwhelming and the soup not only warmed me up but I enjoyed it in the process.  Felix had the Bun Thit Nuong Chay Gio - Vermicelli with BBQ Pork and Imperial Rolls - which he enjoyed but the pork was strange (which I've noticed in the past.)  

From past experience: the fried squid and the imperial rolls (fried egg rolls) are good.
author: Nicole N.

description:
Wednesday afternoon at 12:00 sharp.  No wait.  

For the two of us, me - rice with tofu, curry sauce and veggies and my friend - seafood rice/noodles, plus tea for both of us - bill came out to be under $14!

Nothing spectacular.  Good lunch meal that's quick and not hard on the wallet.  Plus portion size is great!
author: Swetha G.

description: I came here for a bowl of Bun last week.  The egg roll on top was big but super-greasy.  The chicken was mostly gristle and the fish sauce was mediocre.  I've had much better, but Vietnamese options in the Mission are limited.  Probably won't be back.
author: Eric S.

description:
Excellent Mission cheap eats with friendly service

I ate here twice. The quantity and quality of food is excellent. First trip I had fish soup, vegetarian spring rolls and iced coffee. It was almost more than I could eat. 

The second time, I just ordered the vegetarian spring rolls. They were served to me fresh, the tofu was warm inside and the vegetables and wrapper were cold. The peanut dipping sauce was slightly spicy and had shreds of carrot. My meal with tip came to $8. That makes this place a winner in my book!
author: Lane G.

description:
Went here last night and my thoughts where this...

It was empty during dinner rush but the food was pretty good.

The wait staff was pretty friendly but lacked service.

I had to ask for more water than once.

The thai ice tea was pretty good

Fairly cheap 

The shrimp and pork rolls were actually good, lots of shrimp and pork.

The place had a good feel to it and it didn't smell funny.

These were the thoughts that were running through my head when i left. it wasn't anything that wowed me or made me tingle. it was a cold night in the city and i was in the mood for pho. I refuse to go to sunflower since i'm scared of fugly waiter guy. i would come back but i hope i find something a lil better in the mission.
author: Lucky M.

description:
Cute little restaurant but spotty service and the food wasn't that great for the price. Both my boyfriend and I had noodle soups. 
I had the large rare steak & beef ball noodle soup.  I like the taste of the noodles and the broth is really yummy. I didn't like how they cut the beef balls in half and the skimpy portions of steak. I wished I had more noodles in my bowl. For $7, I expected a bit more food. I liked how they constantly filled up my water and the Thai ice is really good too.
author: Gladys C.

description:
I admit to not knowing a whole lot about Vietnamese food and whether or not it is authentic, but I know I like it and have eaten a range from fusion to just weird stuff so H and I decided to pop in and yeah, it's a hole in the wall - but hey, it's the Mission, right? - and yeah, there was a party of 12 but really, I couldn't really fault it. 

The waiter was a bit harried because of the party and said he'd get the appetizer out quickly but the dinner would take a few minutes because of the party - because they cook the dinners fresh each time! Good sign.

The Deep Fried Quail appetizer was superb! It was juicy meat and crunchy skin, flavorful but not gamey, and, with a squirt of fresh lime, delightful! After they had a tug of war to get the plates with little piles of bones off the table (we were sucking on them, it was so good) they served the main course, which, by the way, wasn't any a longer wait than most restaurants. 

Had eggplant with some tofu thrown in (tasty), and fresh steaming rice (I am a rice snob), and the chicken lemongrass vermicelli noodles (we'd ordered beef but, whatever!) - all of which were good...

but the quail! The quail! I'd go there just for the quail (and order two!).
author: Mi M.

description: The only thing better then pho when you are hung over is pho delivered when you are hung over.  TT2 delivers piping hot pho to your door steps.
author: Wakako U.

description: Cheap, good vietnamese food in the heart of the mission. I always get the medium sized pho, and i am plenty full afterwards. Today I ordered the seafood noodle soup and got only few bits of seafood here and there, but the broth was yum. Quick service, clean place. Would recommend if you're in the area and want a warm tummy full of pho.
author: Kat D.

description: The food here is fantastic. With this on the same block as Sunflower, I would never go back when this is right down the block.  I think the real win here that they truly grill their meats and seafood.  The service is seriously lacking, but that won't stop me.  Too bad I don't live closer I would get takeout every damn day.  Go.
author: e w.

description:
UPDATED REVIEW: 
I'm sad to say I'm docking 2 stars from Thanh Tam II. I stopped by for a late lunch today, after a long hiatus from my last visit, and had a pretty disappointing experience. The dining room was a mess, it took the owner a while to notice me and take my order. She may have been in a bad mood, as she was pretty curt with me, and I just felt negative vibes from her. 

Despite the experience, the iced coffee was a delicious as I remember, and my grilled shrimp & pork over cold noodle was yummy. Lovely char on the shrimp, but not chewy and tender grilled pork with lots of garlic and peanuts on top. I still maintain good for takeout, but I don't think I'll be popping in to dine ever. :(
-----------------------------------

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
i've been eating at thanh tam on and off since it opened. i used to come weekly, and sometimes even on the weekends. i feel i've patronized this place enough to figure out what works and what doesn't.

thanh tam knows how to grill meat. order anything with grilled meat and it will arrive beautifully charred on the edges and carmelized, as grilled meat should. that said, any of the cold noodle (bun) dishes with grilled pork are very tasty. if you can, stick with grilled pork -- it's their specialty. i'm not crazy about the 5spice chicken or grilled beef, and have had a rogue bowl of bun with "warm" noodles, that was just wrong. my personal fave is bun with grilled pork & shrimp -- yum!

a few of the appetizers and specialty dishes are hits and kick my ass hard.
apps:
- shrimp & pork spring roll, vegetarian spring roll (look under veg dishes). the peanut sauce w/a little chili added is too good.
- fried wontons
- fried quail (my friend swears by this)
- salt & pepper squid (tender, salty & spicy -- sublime when it's done right)
- vietnamese pancake w/mint & lettuce

salads: any of the beef salads with a squeeze of lemon

soup: most of the soups won't knock your socks off, but they're okay, and filling. try the westlake soup.

entrees:
- any of the grilled pork dishes under the vietnamese specialty section
- butter garlic chow mein under vegetarian (garlicky!)

drinks:
- the iced coffee is the bomb, and i cannot get enough
- the lemon soda can be sweet, but dilute it on a hot day and it's very refreshing

a few observations and expectations:
- avoid the chinese dishes (they're mediocre and often bland)
- dishes can be inconsistent especially when the owner is not around
- it's not a true pho joint, so i don't expect fireworks in this area, but most folks come here just for pho (although the beef stew is very good)
- the bathroom is always clean

thanh tam is a family-run restaurant, so do not have mission hipster expectations when dining here. the owner's son runs the dining room, her photo watches over the restaurant, and her niece is pictured on the menu (a little factoid). service can sometimes be slow, and not totally on top of their game, but i forgive them for these shortcomings. they've always served a good meal, and it doesn't pretend to be what it is not.

i liken this place to a real neighborhood, getting-to-know-you kind of place. i often run into friends here, and sometimes meet new people. that's rare on valencia, these days.
author: Antoi C.

description:
This place is yumlicious.. and cheaplicious!  I love the great selection of pho.  Beef, tripe, seafood, chicken, combo... There are some Chinese dishes, too, but I almost always stick to the pho whenever I come here. my other half always orders the grilled chicken and whatever over rice.  Whenever I sneak a bite, it's always really good - always containing the five flavors essential to Asian cuisine.  

The wine selection isn't very good, but have their Vietnamese beer - Saigon or Tiger - with your meal.
author: B Y.

description:
I can think of few things more appealing than pho when I'm feeling under the weather.  Whether my lethargy is from a simple lack of sleep, a nasty hangover, or the common cold, sitting down to a steaming bowl of broth redolent of that magical combination of fish sauce and lemongrass makes me sigh with relief.  Now this may not be the superlative "best" pho out there; this distinction seems to be a point of contention amongst the pho lovers out there (personally, my loyalty lies with Turtle Tower), but the pho at Thanh Tam is pretty satisfying regardless.  I have yet to try anything else aside from the chicken pho/pho ga (I think its called "shredded chicken noodle soup" on this menu) so this review is primarily for that, although I have been tempted by their other offerings.  Serving sizes are large;I have yet to finish the medium bowl, and it comes with the requisite assortment of bean sprouts, Thai basil, lemon wedges, and slices of Jalapeño (standard sauces one might expect at a Vietnamese restaurant are also on the table).

My main quibble with Thanh Tam II lies in the service, which seems to echo throughout others reviews of this restaurant.  The last time I ate here (last night) the staff started to turn away customers at 9 PM, despite having their posted hours of business listed as not closing til 10.  We were the last ones there at 9:30 and I felt a bit rushed, but it wasn't a deal breaker for me.  Otherwise (and on other occasions) I've found that the staff here do an acceptable job, though without any flourish that one might expect from a more upscale joint.  Honestly though, I kind of appreciate the hands-off approach they take here service wise, I'm here to eat my food, not to chat it up with the waiter/waitress.  The ambiance is so-so, not remarkable one way or another.  

Bonus point: they scored 92 (out of 100) on their restaurant inspection, which isn't perfect, but certainly hasn't skeeved me out from returning (and is a few points higher than my beloved Turtle Tower at 88). 

Bottom line: come here expecting good food with relatively slow but otherwise unremarkable (hands-off?) service and you'll leave satisfied.  Get the chicken pho!
author: Nicole P.

description:
This review is for 
Spicy chicken with Lemon Grass Noodle: $6.50
Beef with Broccoli: $5.95

Broccoli beef was bland.  Spicy chicken with lemon grass noodle was yummy, reminiscent of Thai beef salad.  Service was poor.  We waited and waited to order, our forks and chop sticks were slammed down in the middle of the table, and Jeff G. waited and waited to get his coke while the waiter watched tv.  The dining room was also extensively smoky with burnt oil smoke.  Pretty expensive for Vietnamese, but a good alternative to Tu Lan after 9pm or on Sundays.  Free delivery is always nice as well, but there is a $15 dollar minimum on delivery and  $10 dollar minimum on credit cards.
author: Matt N.

description:
Evergreen is my Vietnamese restaurant of choice in Mission, but it doesn't open on Sundays.  We tried to go to Sunflower next based on yelper recommendations, but the place wasn't open until 1230, and we were hungry at noon.

This was not a bad alternative.  Very clean, and we didn't have much problem with service.  Then again, we lucked out by being the only customers.

My out-of-town guest loved his pho, and I enjoyed my shrimp cake sugar cane rice noodle.  Will probably still go to Evergreen b/c it has better entrees.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I only eat one thing so thats why i give it a 4. I use to get the broccoli chicken with fried rice. then i changed it up to broccoli tofu w/ fried rice. Its 7 bucks but i crave the shit. I love it. the Fried rice is bomb too. its that soft mushy kind. So if you want chinese food got to Yum Yums next door but order the fried rice at this place. Yum yums fried rice blows. 

The Eggrolls here are bomb . the to go packages are reusable too. 

-Tons of food on your plate
-fried rice is the yepa yepa yepa
-reusable togo packaging

only delivers after 5 so that sucks...
author: Richard J.

description:
Had the pho here and it really hit the spot.  It's a good place to go to get your Vietnamese food fix and the service is quick. 
The night I went, they had a Jackie Chan movie from Hong Kong playing on a tv mounted in the corner of the restaurant.  It had spanish subtitles.  Weird.
author: Naomi N.

description:
So we came here after church. I guess this is the place to be for dinner for most people who are hungry for vietnamese/chinese. Very attentive service and good food. I had the usual bbq chicken vermicelli and my husband ordered the rice dish with the bbq chicken. We also ordered the spring rolls and egg rolls. Everthing was very good. Only a buck more than your usual pho places. We didn't mind since the portions were very generous.
I didn't give it the full 5 stars because they didn not have the banh mi sandwiches on the menu. Too bad, but we still will come back again.
author: Mauling W.

description: My friend and I fell in to Thanh Tam on a rainy afternoon. The pho was fabulous, the vietnamese sandwich very authentic - even though the meat was ... well ... not perfect. The service was a bit slow and the waitress ... a bit chilly... but I'd still go back for the Pho. My friend, a Pho afficianado, deemed the Pho "very good."
author: joan g.

description:
it's a pho stop in the middle of mission. it has no competition, so it can be whatever it wants and it will still be in business.

msg was just right in my soup, but besides the flavor of the msg, i really didn't taste much beef broth, or any other spices for that matter. i'm just glad i didn't walk out with a numb elbow.

this district is known for its dirty mexican food, and bacon wrapped hot dog, not really for the vietnamese dishes. but an abundant amount of bars for the fodder that you're about to have with the guy who sells books at the corner of Valencia and 16th.

be careful if you're driving. the parking Nazi's are always out to brand you with their fines. side walk blocking, street cleaning, or if your car is jewish, you're not getting any mercy from them.  GrRrRR
author: Noy K.

description: Best tofu vermicelli in the mission and they deliver!  Price is super reasonable. They almost always have a table available and their food is yummy.  Its great for super casual, but certainly not upscale.
author: Foreign D.

description: Excellent lemongrass over noodles and yellow curry.  Some dishes are very bland.
author: Ziadee C.

description:
I wasn't drunk like the time I enjoyed "Vietnam" in North Beach so that's the preface. I had the pork chop over rice, Very ok, of course the Vietnamese version of pork chop can be a bit deceiving, it's 3 thin slices of pork, does have some with bone, the meat is uneven, some is really good, some fat (not bad) and some be dryness

There's some cucumbers and carrots, the ngoc mam is just ok

I like that they take credit card, $6 and change
author: xo x.

description:
Finding this place was a serendipitous mistake - a friend and I were aiming for Yum-yum House next door but got distracted.

This is officially my favorite Vietnamese place in the city.  Yes, I've been to Sunflower down the street, but I've never craved anything on their menu like I crave Thanh Tam II's tofu lemongrass over noodles.  I require it with monthly (if not weekly) regularity.  It completes me.  

This place is very low-key, no-frills, hole-in-the-wall, and that's my idea of a good time.  The staff is really friendly and attentive and the food is tasty, not expensive and a nice not-greasy alternative to other food joints in the area.  My partner swears by the clay pots and vegetable pho (which is not on the menu, but which they will make for her whenever she wants it).  

I'm getting hungry just writing about it.
author: Dani B.

description:
Just two buildings down from my fiancee's place, this nook of Vietnamese goodness makes delightful dishes. Personally unfamiliar with "authentic" Vietnamese cuisine, Than Tam receives a strong four stars solely on good eats.  Their dishes food, whether it's the second time back or the fiftieth, are consistent.

I enjoy the rice dishes chicken, pork, beef or vegetable.  They're all good.  I've had better pho at other places, but it's decent here.  My one complaint would have to be the women staff.  The last time I was here and the restaurant was being "handled" by the women staff, shit was hitting the fan.  They were behind on orders, in a panic, unapologetic, and openly avoiding the continuously ringing phone.  Granted it could have been a bad night, but the fact that they were in a major panic and melt down is very disheartening. To think that they were in such upheaval that they refused to answer the phones makes me genuinely angry.  So, every time I plan on eating here, I have to peer through the window to see who's "running" the restaurant (just to make sure it's not them).
author: Darkie L.

description: Tofu sandwich is delicious, lemongrass tofu dishes are good.  Just had price increases on their newly printed menus.  Staff is not very friendly but the sandwich makes up for it.
author: K W.

description: Order was delivered very quickly.  It took maybe 25 minutes instead of the quoted 40.  That's awesome.  I had the grilled pork & egg roll over rice, beef pho, sesame beef, and some extra imperial rolls.  All of it was exactly what I was craving.  And it's all reasonably priced, too.  I'm very happy to know this place delivers to my place.
author: Richard Q.

description: I'd call it three and a half stars - but with an extra half star for the squid we had.  I love that there's vietnamese in the mission, but at the same time the price points are a little high for vietnamese. The pho was serviceable, the broth was ok, but not insanely great depth of flavor. Overall, the pho was good. No tendon was on offer though, only tripe and rare steak, brisket and meatball. They did have a nice array of pho ga though and a HUGE selection of bun, rice dishes and other items. We sampled the salt and pepper squid which was DELISH. Salty, peppery, superbly crisp batter and big pieces of squid that were tender and cut just right. FAB.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I love bun, especially the Imperial Roll and BBQ Beef bun, and Thanh Tam II makes a fair representative of the species.

Imperial Rolls are decently sized and well fried, but seem under spiced to my taste and unvaried in their consistency --- porky, pork pork.

The BBQ beef is a perky  reddish color, plenty beefy and tender, but again lacking in any special flavor.

The Bun base is great though, not simply a limp pile of noodle --- it's got a solid salad under-layer with cilantro, mint, and pickly cucumber and carrot.   All normal Bun toppings are included, but are not especially numerous or memorable.

The price is super (in the mission its really exceptional), and the menu is expansive, including several bun varieties I havn't found elsewhere .  The Pho is also excellent.
author: Gustie L.

description:
I got the pork and rice and it was delicious.  It was fresh and simply made.  My friends' food looked awesome as well..and the eggplant dish was great.   Lots of sauce, just like a like it, but without it being MSG-y and overpowering.  

 The price is completely affordable.  The decor and atmosphere is not impressive so do not take a first date there, however,  it's a great place to go with friends.   The service is a little off...I think she was confused with the amount of tables she had.
author: Ann M.

description: This place wins. I tried the tofu salad and my partner in crime got the vegetable noodles. We don't know what they put in each, but they were significantly more interesting than our usual at Sunflower. More tang, more spice... f yes.
author: Amber K.

description:
I go back and forth about Thanh Tam II. I get take-out from here a lot (okay, I live upstairs...it's just so damned convenient!), and some things are definitely better than others.

The good:
- curry tofu. The tofu is a good spongy texture and soaks up sauce perfectly. The sauce is flavorful, has the right amount of spice, and the dish has a good assortment of veggies.
- vermicelli with grilled chicken and egg rolls. Tasty chicken (dark meat, which I prefer, but not too fatty), nicely crispy pork "egg rolls" (imperial rolls), an allover good combination of meat, rolls, noodles and lettuce/cucumber.

The not-so-good:
- The grilled pork (tried with vermicelli and alone) is just too fatty/greasy for me.
- spicy chicken with lemongrass. It's okay, but not as flavorful as it should be, and doesn't hold a candle to Sunflower across the street.

The menu is ridiculously and needlessly huge, given that the "Vietnamese Style BBQ Meat" section is mostly a repeat of the "BBQ Meat Vermicelli Noodle" section, except over rice rather than noodles. I find that more and more when I order from here, I really only get the "good" items listed above. The taller half also orders and enjoys the Combination Wonton Soup, which I think is okay, but a little salty. I

f you live in the neighborhood, it's worth getting food here a few different times to figure out what you like, since it's cheap and fast, but if not it's kind of hit or miss.
author: Valerie M.

description: This place is great in my book. Better than Sunflower across the street, and featuring totally rad service. I had the herb & squid salad, and the squid was perfectly cooked. The server overheard my friend and I talking about delivery service (or rather, my bemoaning that my husband would never allow it) and he deftly tucked a takeout menu under my plate as he passed. Awesome. This is great food, fairly priced, served by nice people - you can rarely get all three in the Mission.
author: Jess F.

description: My review is based on the service - they are very rude and impatient.  I've ordered food from them two times and it's been the same - they blamed me for them getting lost upon delivery.  I live in a pretty well known area (Caltrain station).  Who's fault is that?
author: Sandy W.

description: I love this place.  Come here at least once a month.  Home cooking vietnamese food.  I love the spring rolls, the vietnamese crepes (banh xeo) and grill pork with vermicelli noodles.
author: Jaime L.

description: Goodness. Fish filets in black bean sauce, supreme fried rice, and veggie imperial rolls. And a 33. Delicious. Excellent waiter, too.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
My wife and I wanted some classic noodle soup. This place delivered and how. It took a little over an hour, but the thinly-sliced raw beef that cooked through when combined with the tangy broth and the bean sprouts and Thai basil.....yum. All of it yum. 

Order from this place when you're sick and want noodle soup.

Can't speak much to anything else on the menu though. Well, we had the shrimp spring rolls, those were good too. But that's it.
author: Mr. R.

description: my go to spot for vietnamese food near mission dolores not because it's good, just because it will satisfy my taste for vietnamese food within walking distance.  Relatively expensive compared to tenderloin vietnamese, but i'll pay the extra few dollars for convenience.  Good sign is that there are mostly asians eating there.
author: LT B.

description: ordered a chicken salad $9.  way over priced.  right when i stuck my fork in to grab a bite... guess what i found?  a piece of hair.  that's it for me.  not coming back!!!!!
author: Mimi S.

description: Y'know, this place actually doesn't suck.  For the price, it's pretty decent Vietnamese food.  The service / ambiance / decor left me looking for more, but the food and price made up for it.  I'd come back but probably go for take out.
author: Ankur P.

description: we been ordering from the mission store for over 5 years but now it closed down... store no.2 is still up and running, still remember the first time order me the two pork chop, shredded pork, two eggs and meat loaf for $7 it was well worth it... almost could finish it every time, no i tired to order the same thing well its $8 now and it doesn't come with two eggs anymore, well you add it just pay more. everything on the plate just got smaller thru the years, used to be like the bomb but now its just ok... kinda went down hill but we still order from this place once in the blue moon...
author: JessePanda C.

description: Spicy beef on lemon vermicelli with very fresh vegetables was light, crisp, refreshing.
author: A J.

description:
Man.  Anyone who doesn't give Thanh Tam five stars is a psycho.  This place is awesome to the core.  I've never eaten there though.  

That said, I order delivery from them at least once a week, between school and work and all, they're consistently awesome, and that never changes.  The delivery, although I'm up at the top of a very high hill in Noe, pretty far away from the restaurant, never takes more than 30 minutes.  The best part is the food is delicious.  The vietnamese eggrolls are awesome, the vegetarian spring rolls are awesome, the pot stickers are awesome, and every single ala carte dish is awesome.  (that i've had).  My favorite dish here is the Spicy curry tofu, its creamy and delicious crammed with bok choy, mushrooms, pea shoots, broccoli, carrots, baby corns and delicious tofu.  Every single time I have it I'm like "Dang.  This is a good curry."

I guess the lesson is, don't judge this joint on the inside.  Stay at home and rent a movie and order it for delivery and you'll fall in love
author: Devon L.

description:
went here or brunch....got the spicy beef with lemongrass noodles (vermicelli) okay food here..i've had better- the prices are same for any vietnamese restaurant...

in conclusion, the place is alright, not a must eat place but if you're starving and have no choice, i guess this place will do
author: AK M.

description: My vermicelli bowl wasn't bad, and neither were my dining companions' Pho dishes.  But the service, or lack thereof, left a bad taste in my mouth.  You're on your own after they take your order.  Head to Sunflower on 16th for a better dining experience with Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Marsha Z.

description: petite portions...premium pricing...bored bland.....pork lacking light char....flame broiled taste none... egg rolls fine crisp out and nice texture in...though tasteless and uneventful flavoring....no fresh drip..iced coffee poor....business appearance mostly from delivery making....simple meal average $ten after tax/tip...plus couple $dollars add drink....
author: Hen A.

description: This place will always be memorable because it was the place where I had my last lunch of 2007 and first dinner of 2008 with a newly found mentor/artist friend. After a day of priming walls and nailing wooden panels together while feet stomp heavily from above (poor neighbors who live above SoEx Gallery). Okay, so that has nothing to do with the food at Thanh Tam II but I was never good at intros. Overall, I had a blast eating the yummy noodle chicken soup (rice noodles, I wouldn't have it any other way) on Day One. Then, on Day Two, I had the #52 (thanks to my friend's recommendation). What a great dish! Rice noodles topped with barbecued chicken, julienned carrots, sprouts and a super crispy pork egg roll! Ugh, can it get any better than that? Who knew I could have a gluttonous affair with one dish. Anyway, order #52!
author: Dorothy S.

description: My favorite, fast, cheap.. well not cheap, vietnamese restaurant in the mission.  The staff is really nice and the fish sauce is fresh.  I like to order the rare beef salad.  Oh boy, they give a huge portion.  Other then that, i enjoy their bbq port cutlet on rice.  I love the authentic aunt in the background screaming at the nephew. it's classic.
author: kevin h.

description: Found our Pho place in the Mission! We had the Imperial Rolls, Wonton Soup and the Five Spice Chicken and they were great! Nice ambiance - neat & clean. Much better than Sunflower across the street which we found a tad dirty.
author: Fiona D.

description:
thanh tam II serves up some tasty pho.  i'd give them five stars if they offered tendon, but their rare beef & tripe pho is still pretty darn yummy - very flavorful broth with well made (tender, but firm) bun lurking in huge quantity underneath.  an unfinishably large portion for only $5.99 - an astoundingly cheap price for any quality food in the mission.  and it's a hell of a lot better than the flavorless pho offered over at sunflower up the block.

the service kind of sucks, but only insofar as they let you know that they don't care about you as a person.  but i've never been kept waiting for an interminable length of time, or been left wanting for eating utensils or sri cha.

i've also been quite pleased with their fresh spring rolls, and i noticed that they have sugar cane shrimp bun on the menu (which i never order because i'm always fiending for some pho when i dine here).  i'll be coming back whenever i'm around 16th and valencia and in need of pho...
author: genevieve g.

description:
i don't think i'll be coming back here again since there are two sunflower outposts across the street.  i gave it a shot tho.  went in for lunch and i was the only person there which made it somewhat lonely and depressing.  not so much that i was eating alone as sometimes i really enjoy eating my myself but when i am the ONLY diner, i start thinking about why there are no other diners, are the owners making a profilt, will they be serving me leftovers, will they have to shut down since no one seems to want to eat there, will they have to collect unemployment soon, and then be on foodstamps......

anyway, the food seemed fresh enough despite my anxiety but it just wasn't anything worth venturing back form.  the spring roll was pretty good but really, it's pretty hard to mess up a spring roll.  the seafood pho i had was really mediocre.  i tasted a scallop that was weird texturally and the broth was fairly greasy.  they didn't give the standard plate of bean sprouts and basil.  they just threw some scant spouts in the soup along w/some cilantro.

they serve "chinese cuisine" as well.  go figure......
author: Bird B.

description: Excellent Fuh! Fast service.. always grab this on the way home from work.
author: Manoj L.

description: Some really good Vietnamese food in its own right. This cozy little spot in the Mission is clean and cheap and makes for a perfect quiet weeknight dinner. Little family owned business (their cute little wide-eyed girl kept popping over to our table to say hello) that is charming and has some really tasty spring rolls as well as some fantastic bun thit nuong (pork vermicelli) and pho. My only complaint is that the pork was a little fatty and it took them awhile to get us our check, so in reality this would be about 3.5 stars, but I'll generously round up. I definitely like this place better than Sunflower down the block...
author: Michael E.

description: Yum Yum! My sister took me to this place and it was awesome! I loved it! As you walk in all you smell are these incredible smells--so divine! I had the butter and garilc chow mein.  The garlic wasn't overpowering at all and it was all the way delicious! I tried some of my sister's. She had the #52. Rice noodles with veggies, beef, and egg roll...OMG..good. My mouth is watering as I write this. Seriously. Just seriously. Try this...Oh, and it's affordable too.
author: Mel P.

description: Cheap and average Vietnamese food with quick service. No ambience, no wait. I prefer this spot to the Chinese restaurant next door that's supposed to be "yum", but not really.
author: Zell C.

description:
Oh you heard the name alright.. the place is called 'Thanh Tam II'.  Don't know where the first location is, but I've been to this spot several times in the last few months. After a long day of running errands or kicking it with my friends, we usually roll up to this spot on a Saturday afternoon.  For me the ultimate objective for lunch is to get something good and cheap to eat, this place takes care of both those key requirements.

The options on the food menu is your typical vietnamese items, I mean if you want Pho, five spice herb chicken, vietnamase rolls, etc... you get the point they probably have it.  

The one killer item though that we always get and come back to, has got to be the appetizer item ' shrimp lobster sugar cane roll'  something along that line.   Just check under the appetizer section and look for those elements you can't miss it.  Anywho,  they bring out a bowl of hot water which is then followed by a stack of dry rice transluscent paper.  Then the ingredients follow..  shrimp lobster meat, vermicelli, mint, basil, jooeaned carrots, fish sauce, crushed peanuts.... the ingredients are all separated.    Oh you know where I'm going with this......   yeah, so the dry rice paper is dipped into the water to make the shell of the roll, followed by the ingredients of your choice...  you make it, if you got skills you can make a good wrap, if not the shit slips out of your hands when you eat.  In either case, that shit is off the hook!  After a long day of activities that appetizer hits the spot, straight to the dome.

Man when shit is good you gotta do the right thing and let the peoples know, check the spot out if you like this type of joint.   One!!
author: marcus o.

description: I went over to check this place out only to realize I'd already been here. The first time I had some pretty mediocre food. I think we ordered two rice plates - a chicken and a veggie one. Was definitely disappointed with the food. However, I went back today and ordered the cold spring rolls and pho to go, and was pleasantly surprised. They give you four reasonable sized rolls in one order of spring rolls, and these were really good with some yummy sauce. The pho was great too, the medium was plenty big and I still have some leftover for lunch tomorrow. I'd def consider getting delivery from here for these two items, assuming they deliver to where I live.
author: Humaira M.

description: I wish I could rate the food here, but unfortunately we were completely ignored the entire 15 mins we were there. Walked in (there was ONE other occupied table). Girl at counter sees us, but doesn't acknowledge. So we sit at a table with menus. After about 5 mins, we had picked our dishes and closed our menus. Waited another 10 mins. No one. How disappointing. We left an went across the street to Sunflower. They might be a little more expensive, but at least they acknowledged us. **shrug**
author: CAM T.

description: I am giving this place three stars because it has a cheap menu, which makes me happy.  They are pretty speedy about bringing you the food, but not so speedy about bringing you the check.  I had the vermicelli with tofu, which I thought was a good portion (enough for two meals, really) and filled me up.  Also, the spring rolls are quite good; the best part by far was the peanut sauce.
author: Joanna S.

description: Still my favorite after 3 years. I keep their number in my cell phone even though I now live in Oakland, because you never know when you are going to need some damn good vietnamese take out on your way home from the city. mmmmm.
author: Jessica T.

description:
this place is a hole in the wall.  i have lived in the mission a year and just recently noticed it.  

this rainy weekend was the perfect weather for pho.  

if you are hungry and cold...stop by and order the medium plate.  prices are reasonable, service is good and we left content and full.
author: Laura G.

description: Pretty decent, authentic Vietnamese food. The pho broth was delicious and the shrimp with scrambled eggs over rice was right up there with the best I've had. The service was slow, as can be expected at a one man show and my tablecloth was ridiculously dirty (I had to force myself not to look down), but it's all about the food at a place like this.
author: Alicia J.

description: This restaurant has exceptionally good fried rice.  I know that seems pathetically pedestrian, but they really do. Their fresh veggie rolls also have just veggies in them, no noodles or tofu or whatnot, and their Imperial Rolls are fantastic.  I have never tried anything more experimental there, but a friend of mine swears by the five-spice chicken and the barbequed pork.
author: Jude F.

description:
great neighborhood noodle place...
it's clean and they have good pho and vermicelli noodle dishes...
definately preferred over sunflower across the street
author: charlotte s.

description: I was a little scared to walk into this place but my girlfriend said she'd been there before and that it was pretty good. I ordered a bbq chicken plate over rice with shrimp. The dish was yummy and they gave a pretty large portion. The chicken wasn't too dry and the shrimp weren't over cooked. Pretty cheap and fast service.
author: elizabeth j.

description: I am a bit spoiled, since I live in the "Little Saigon" area of the TL, but this place was decent.  Shared the deep fried quail appetizer with a friend and, though it looked scary, it tasted really good.  I got a BBQ pork and shrimp vermicelli (bun) bowl which was okay - the shrimp were very tasty, but instead of big green lettuce leaves and bean sprouts in the bottom of the bowl, there was just shredded iceberg, which was a disappointment.
author: claire l.

description: Depressing decor that combined with a gloomy gray San Francisco day feels like the life has been drained from you. The service is awful the waitresses and waiters spend more time watching Vietnamese television than tending to your needs (i.e. more water please). Three stars because I come here often about twice a month. The chicken noodle soup ($5) is huge and the vermicelli noodle dishes are super tasty. Eating here is better and cheaper than making food at home.
author: Kat F.

description: My favorite vietnamese restaurant in the city! We dine here at least twice a week and we always order the imperial rolls (mmmhhhhhm), grilled pork w/vermicelli and grilled beef vermicelli. I think they have the best imperial rolls around. They're always consistent with the food and the service is awesom!
author: Dhoris P.

description: A sudden jones for cripsy noodles lead me to this place last Sunday.   Been here a handful of times.  Quick, cheap(er) and good.
author: Michelle C.

description: Great Vietnamese hole in the wall, almost lost amongst the many restaurants around Valencia and 16th/17th.  They do a good job of my staple go-to dish at Vietnamese restaurants: grilled sliced pork with rice.  Good (typical) Thai iced tea and excellent yummmmy candied fried banana with ice cream.  Cheap too (as implied by "hole in the wall").
author: Chris P.

description:
food was average. tasted a-ok, nothing that blew our socks off. got some soup, one veggie and one chicken dish (a la carte), and there were leftovers. 

the food came quickly, portions were decent... we especially enjoyed the low production war movie on the tv, though it didn't seem to fit in with the whole restaurant motif.

only thing was our waitress. she seemed to be really pissed off or uninterested or annoyed. :(. sad.
author: monkey l.

description: Lemongrass tofu is .... amazing!!   Fabulous soups.  Fresh ingredients, vibrant flavors.  Very informal, family-run atmosphere.  Inexpensive and extremely tasty.    Two can eat well here for under $20.
author: David S.

description: After one of my friends threw a fit we decided to eat here. I didn't really get that adventurous with their food though. Just simple beef and broccoli which was pretty good for the most part. But the restaurant was so smokey it was kind of unpleasant.
author: Tiffany D.

description: My new favorite neighborhood Vietnamese! My BF and I by chance ended up going there with then intent on going to another, more crowded restaurant. We were really in a rush to have a quick dinner before heading to a friend's party and came across Thanh Tam. It is definitely no frills, and cheap. But, service is efficient and friendly and they serve all the basics. I am addicted to the raw beef in lemon sauce appetizer and my BF loves their imperial egg rolls.  The also have 33 beer! Try not to get seated by the door as it is very drafty. They should get a curtain to prevent this.
author: Sally T.

description:
this place gave me horrible customer service. The waiter left our table in the middle of ordering our food to answer a phone when there's 3 other people standing next to the phone doing nothing. I mean, is it that hard to just pick it up and say hello this is thanh tam??

The food here is only okay at best. I can't give this place one star only because at the very least they gave us free dessert at the end. I suppose that can count for something. 

in short: one time only restaurant, don't bother coming here if you want some good food to fill your tummy.
author: tim y.

description: As a Vietnamese person marooned in the land of taquerias, it's really nice to have a serviceable Vietnamese restaurant nearby. It's not the greatest in the world but they do the simple noodle and rice dishes well.  A real Vietnamese joint that caters to its compatriots would serve more fatty questionable cuts of meat where this place serves more lean, boring cuts of meat that suit the modern western palate.
author: Andy L.

description:
i thought this place was decent for the price and location. i had the chicken with lemon grass and noodles. i thought it was pretty good, but it had too many red onions. everyone else i can with seemed to have enjoyed their meals too.

the restaurent itself was smokey for the most part, which was uncomfortable.
author: selma s.

description: Deserves 5 stars, not because you go there expecting the most amazing meal you've eaten in your life, but because its fast, cheap, and the grilled pork is damn tasty. That's bout it. If you're in the Mission and needing a good cheap noodle joint, search no further.
author: Mike B.

description:
Thursday night, around 8pm
I called to get an order delivered but the server couldn't understand me nor my boyfriend. Nicely, another person from the restaurant called me back without my asking. 

Anyway, we decided that we'd go along and eat in. When we arrived the place was full of BBQ chicken smoke. Because we'd heard that the food was good we decided to stay, otherwise we would have left. There was 1 other couple and 1 solo person in the large restaurant when we arrived. 

We ordered Beef with Lemon Grass and Chicken and Egg Roll Vermicelli. Instead of beef, chicken was delivered. We sent it back. The beef when it arrived was tender, but tasted only of hot sauce. The chicken was bland. 

We left smelling like a barbecue and sweating hot sauce. My advice... go to Sunflower.
author: Chris W.

description: Good Service, Great Spring Rolls and Pork with Noodles.  Great Price.  Worth it every time.
author: M K.

description: I LOVE Thanh Tam's Vietnamese crepe (Banh Xeo); it's got wonderful texture and all of the flavor.  The pho is good here; basic soup is easy. Try their salt and pepper ribs; they are AMAZING!  Highly recommend this place; yes, great Vietnamese in the Mission!
author: Amy N.

description: Although Elle Decor may never step foot in this restaurant, they are missing something....which is the best beef pho broth in the mission.   All the hipsters can head over to sunflower for their vegetarian fares, but this Vietnamese pho snob is sipping Thanh Tam II's soup with the Cheshire cat's grin at what the ignorantis are missing...I certainly don't mind not having to wait in a long line since the secret is not out.
author: Dat P.

description: We eat here all the time - before kids, sometime multiple times a week, now maybe every other week.  I think the beef pho is better at sunflower, but here they have the best noodle bowls EVER.  Get the one with egg rolls and bbq pork.  Also, their soups other than the pho.  Also, spicy eggplant and tofu.  also the salt and pepper ribs appetizer.  also their chow fun is pretty decent.
author: korin y.

description: not too shabby, good for a quick pho fix. phooooooo....
author: Jeremy H.

description: not bad pho. meat quality could have been better on the pho tai, but service was quick. soup was on the table in no time. did the trick for my pho fix.
author: Tom H.

description: i come to satisfy my pho craving when i don't feel like going to clement area, which is pretty much the case usually. i discovered a new dish there  that is ubberly tasty. when i go back there and find out what it's called, i'll name it. it's fried noodles shaped like a bowl with veggies and/or meat on top. super tasty. otherwise, i like their vermicelli noodles, eggplant and things. service is good, food tasty.  a solid 4 stars
author: Jen R.

description: Great place for Vietnamese in the Mission. One of the closest thing to an authentic Vietnamese restaurant. Craving pho is a common problem for me...and when it happens, I usually come here. The service has never been that great (I usually have to wave down one of the staff watching TV for the check), but overall the experience is good. Food is generally good to excellent. I get the large pho dac biet most of the time. I can probably have two of these. Lately I've been ordering up a storm with rice plates. The grilled pork here is pretty awesome. I haven't been disappointed yet.
author: Young T.

description: so this is a quick fix vietnamese joint with good pho. good thai iced tea too, they give you a parfait glass with only a little ice. i came here for pho tai and i got what went for. it was perfectly lit and i sat against a wall in a small corner that just made me feel good. i had a nice dinner and you should go there and do the same. it's pretty cheap, compared to other places in the neighborood. it's also the most i've ever paid for pho in my entire life.
author: oskar p.

description: another unsuccesful attempt at finding an enjoyable vietnamese meal. the food was unexceptional, the waitstaff was elsewhere and the four crazed drug addicts at the next table were loud and distracting. and to really add insult to injury, my fortune cookie was stale.
author: Alex D.
